idioms.example: Your bike’s in bad shape. You’re ready for Bicycle Maintenance 101.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the supposed practice of assigning 101 as the number of any introductory college class.

idioms.example: Why is she here? That’s the $64,000 question, isn’t it?
idioms.origin: Alludes to an American TV quiz show of the 1950s called The $64,000 Question in which a contestant could win $64,000 with the correct answer to the final, hardest question.

idioms.example: I don’t have much time. Just give me the 30,000-foot view.
That restaurant is A-1.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the risk-management firm Lloyd’s of London’s highest rating on hull and rigging, respectively, of merchant sailing ships.

idioms.example: Making a decision regarding that much money is well above my pay grade.
His aptitude test is his ace in the hole. They can hardly deny him admission now.
idioms.origin: Alludes to a form of poker in which the single face-down card is called the hole card.

idioms.example: This debate isn’t over yet. She has an ace up her sleeve.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the supposed practice of cheating at poker by concealing an ace up one’s sleeve.

idioms.example: She’s a great tennis player, but her serve is her Achilles heel.
idioms.origin: Alludes to Greek mythology, in which the warrior Achilles was dipped by his mother in the river Styx and so became invulnerable except where she held him by one of his heels.

idioms.example: OK, this is the acid test – does it go fast enough?
idioms.origin: Alludes to the application of nitric acid to determine whether ore contains gold.

idioms.example: His proposal was rejected across the board.
It goes against her grain to be deceitful.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to carpentry, where wood is damaged when planed against the grain.

idioms.example: They’re ahead of the curve in adopting this technology.
When they have a fight, they tend to air their dirty laundry.
His manager is providing air cover while he works on the project.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the military practice of protecting ground forces with air forces.
Alludes to The Rime of the Ancient Mariner by Samuel Taylor Coleridge.

idioms.paraphrase: no one can predict what will happen
idioms.example: Now that Andy is injured and can’t play, all bets are off.
idioms.origin: Alludes to gambling, where all existing bets may be called off if the original conditions change dramatically.

idioms.example: Put your regular work aside for today. It’s all hands on deck to handle the new order.
idioms.origin: Alludes to sailing, where all crew members are called into action in an emergency.

idioms.example: Are you all squared away? Is there anything else you need?
She’s the alpha female around here. No one challenges her decisions.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice of labeling the dominant male or female in a wolf pack as the alpha.

idioms.example: It’s a real alphabet soup in my classroom, with students from every part of the globe.
Flunking that course was another nail in her coffin.
I’m so desperate that any job offer looks good. I’ll take any port in a storm.
Andy’s the apple of her grandmother’s eye and she’s completely spoiled.
The armchair quarterbacks are unanimous in their criticism, but they don’t have to make decisions under pressure.
Andy was completely prepared for their questions. He was armed to the teeth with facts and figures.
idioms.comment: Implies preparation for an adversarial situation.

idioms.example: I thought this would be a tough quiz, but it’s as easy as pie.
Since her mother’s diagnosis, Andy’s been completely nonfunctional. She’s just asleep at the wheel.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the situation of someone falling asleep at the controls of an automobile or locomotive.
nautical: metal ball on end of staff for caulking or as a weapon

idioms.keywords: at the drop of a hat
idioms.example: Andy is easily distracted. He’ll stop studying at the drop of a hat.
Andy’s won his last several cases. He’s at the top of his game.
Andy was really upset. She had an ax to grind and wouldn’t be pacified.
After Andy’s mistake was discovered, he had to back and fill on his project plan.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the maneuver used on sailing ships of alternately backing and filling the sails to steer when the rudder isn’t effective.

idioms.example: Now that she’s recovered from her injury, she’s back in the saddle running the squad.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the notion that one should remount a horse after falling to regain confidence.

idioms.example: Andy backed the wrong horse for CEO and now she’s been stripped of her responsibilities.
idioms.origin: Alludes to gambling on horse racing.

idioms.example: We’re back to square one. Our plan has been completely rejected.
idioms.origin: Alludes to some board games, where returning to square one is a setback.

idioms.example: That experiment didn’t work out so well. I guess it’s back to the drawing board.
We’re running out of money for this effort, so it’s back to the well.
That’s the way the Senate works. It’s all backroom deals and the public never knows what’s going on.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the perhaps apocryphal belief that many bars having a back room where privileged individuals could meet and negotiate.

idioms.example: The ball’s in your court, Andy. What we do next is your decision.
idioms.origin: Alludes to tennis, where one must take action when the ball is returned to one’s court.

idioms.paraphrase: seek results in the wrong place
idioms.example: I thought I’d solved the problem, but I was barking up the wrong tree.
idioms.origin: Alludes to hunting with a pack of hounds, which is supposed to corner an animal up a tree and bark as a signal.

idioms.example: She too tired to fix dinner. She’s a basket case after her stressful week at work.
I haven’t missed a question yet. I’m batting a thousand.
idioms.origin: Alludes to baseball, where a thousand is a perfect batting average.
Alludes to the nautical situation in which one ship approaches, or bears down, on another.

idioms.example: Andy could not bring herself to ask the difficult question. She just kept beating around the bush.
idioms.origin: Perhaps alludes to the hunting practice in colonial India of having assistants beat the bushes to flush prey.

idioms.example: Andy’s got a bee in her bonnet about a new approach. She can’t let it go until we discuss it.
They’re behind the curve in adopting this technology.
Andy has put things off, and how he’s behind the eight ball to get his work done.
idioms.origin: Alludes to billiards, where in some games having the cue ball behind the eight ball is a disadvantageous position.

idioms.example: Andy doesn’t like attention. He prefers to work behind the scenes to get things done.
idioms.origin: Alludes to theater, where much important activity goes on off stage.

idioms.example: Andy’s presentation had lots of bells and whistles, but there really wasn’t much substance.
Wow, Andy did a complete belly flop in her presentation.
That decision is really below my pay grade. You can handle it.
Andy thinks that online grocery shopping is the best thing since sliced bread.
idioms.comment: Usually used facetiously.

idioms.example: I’ll bet you dollars to donuts that he’ll win this round.

idioms.keywords: between the devil and the deep blue sea
idioms.example: Remaining unemployed or taking a job he doesn’t want — Andy’s caught between the devil and the deep blue sea.
Andy’s behavior the other night was way beyond the pale.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical use of pales, or stakes, to define boundaries.

idioms.example: Andy hasn’t convinced them on his own, so now he’s bringing in the big guns.
Don’t go in there — the big wigs are having a meeting.
I can’t be bothered with that right now. I’ve got bigger fish to fry.
Andy’s drunk and now he’s in the pool in nothing but his birthday suit.
OK, guess it’s time to bite the bullet and get started on this paper.
idioms.comment: Implies a painful or difficult action.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice in pre-anesthetic surgery days of giving the patient a bullet or other object to bite on during intense pain.

idioms.example: Andy got married over the summer. Another confirmed bachelor bites the dust.
idioms.origin: Perhaps alludes to an early British Army euphemism for getting shot.

idioms.example: Bite your tongue, young man! You should not say such things about anyone.
They’re way behind, but they’ll keep playing hard until the bitter end.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the nautical phrase indicating the end of any line which is opposite the working end.

idioms.example: Not getting that job was a bitter pill for Andy to swallow
Unlike his siblings, Andy never went to go to college. I guess he’s the black sheep of the family.
idioms.comment: Implies that the family member is also more or less undesirable.

idioms.example: Andy’s been given a blank check on this project, so now she’d better get it done.
Andy is blazing a trail for other hopeful young women athletes to follow.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice of marking a new trail by cutting the bark of a tree to make a blaze.

idioms.example: Andy’s such a bleeding heart. He gives a buck to every panhandler.
idioms.comment: Usually used pejoratively.

idioms.example: Andy’s first app was a block buster. Now’s she’s got the backing to do any app she wants.
There’s blood in the water after Andy’s failure, and now others are criticizing her for every little detail.
Andy’s promotion looks like blood money after his betrayal of his colleague.
idioms.origin: payment for a wound?

idioms.example: Andy likes to blow her own horn even for small accomplishments.
They don’t mean any harm. They’re just blowing off steam after waiting so long for a victory.
idioms.origin: Perhaps alludes to the practice of releasing pressure in a steam engine by releasing steam.

idioms.example: Geez, did I ever blow that call. I should have taken his first offer.
idioms.origin: Alludes to sports, in reference to an official making an apparently incorrect decision.

idioms.example: He gave us the blow-by-blow account of his interview, much more than we needed to hear.
idioms.origin: Alludes to boxing, where an announcer may detail every blow struck.

idioms.example: Andy’s a blue chip recruit. She’ll add real offensive power to the team.
idioms.origin: Alludes to poker, where the blue chips are usually assigned the highest value.

idioms.example: Andy never allowed himself to be pinned down. He bobbed and weaved beautifully on every question.
idioms.origin: Alludes to boxing, where a competitor can bob his head and weave around as a defensive maneuver.

idioms.example: The committee’s decision was a body blow to their campaign for new rules.
idioms.origin: Alludes to boxing, where a solid blow to the body can stun an opponent.

idioms.example: The election was a complete disaster. What’s the body count?
idioms.origin: Alludes to military battles, where the damage is measured by the count of dead and wounded.

idioms.example: Well, that was a bolt from the blue! I never expected her to show up.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the notion that a lightning bolt may strike out of clear blue sky.

idioms.paraphrase: a contentious issue to discuss with (one)
idioms.example: Andy, I’ve got a bone to pick with you. I thought you agreed with our strategy.
I need to bone up on my physics a bit. This problem’s got me stymied.
She lives in the boon docks. She has a two-hour commute each way every day!

idioms.paraphrase: people in place and in action
idioms.example: We can’t make any sales remotely in Europe. We need boots on the ground.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the military notion that actual soldiers must be present for effectiveness in a given situation.

idioms.keywords: born on third base and thinks (one) hit a triple
idioms.paraphrase: born to advantage but thinks (one) is highly accomplished
idioms.example: He can’t understand their difficulties, because he was born on third base and thinks he hit a triple.
idioms.origin: Alludes to baseball, where hitting a triple is a significant achievement.

idioms.keywords: born with a silver spoon in (one’s) mouth
idioms.example: He was born with a silver spoon in his mouth and has never dealt with adversity.
I don’t need to hear the whole argument. Just tell me the bottom line.
idioms.origin: Alludes to accounting, where the bottom line in a financial statement shows the overall status of a business.

idioms.example: In the old Hollywood movies the villain always bought the farm.
idioms.comment: Usually used informally and jokingly.

idioms.example: The brass hats have arrived, so be on your best behavior.

idioms.origin: Alludes to the dystopian book Brave New World by Aldous Huxley.

idioms.example: We can’t afford this house. Buying it would break the bank.
Andy is really shy. It’s up to you to break the ice.
Andy is quite the performer. Her performance brought down the house.
Andy is an interesting and eccentric guy. They broke the mold after him.
idioms.origin: Alludes to sculpture, where multiple copies of a statue can be made from a single mold.

idioms.example: Andy’s such a brown noser. She’d never disagree with the teacher.
I got some nice brownie points for sending the boss a sympathy card.

idioms.paraphrase: (one’s) list of places to go and things to see
idioms.example: Traveling to New Zealand has always been on my bucket list.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the idiom kick the bucket to refer to dying, indicating the things one wants to do before dying.

idioms.example: Andy’s hoping for a successful startup, but I think he’s building castles in the air.
Nice work on that essay. Your analysis hit the bull’s eye.
idioms.origin: grommet serving as a fair lead

idioms.example: That professor can be a bit preachy. He takes advantage of his bully pulpit much too often.
No, we didn’t have a reservation, but that was no reason to give us the bum’s rush.
The coach has a bumper crop of exciting young athletes this year.
idioms.origin: from full glass called a "bumper"

idioms.example: What a bunch of yahoos! They have no idea what they’re doing.
idioms.comment: Can also imply a group of boors.
idioms.origin: Alludes to a race of brutes in Jonathan Swift's book Gulliver’s Travels.

idioms.example: Quit your job if you have to, but there’s no reason to burn your bridges. You may work with some of these folks again.

idioms.keywords: burn the candle at both ends
idioms.example: I’ve got final exams coming up and I’m supposed to work overtime this week too, but I can’t continue burning the candle at both ends for long.
With the trial date coming up, Andy and her assistant are burning the midnight oil, reviewing all the evidence and related cases.
His poor attitude has been a burr under my saddle for some time now.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the fact that a burr or similar item under a saddle irritates and unsettles the horse.

idioms.example: We’ve had our disagreements, but I think it’s time to bury the hatchet for the good of the project.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the perhaps apocryphal tradition that Native Americans ceased hostilities by symbolically striking a tomahawk, or hatchet, into the ground.

idioms.example: That was very poor sportsmanship, really bush league behavior.
Andy always butters up the graduate assistants, hoping for more lenient grading.
I agree with your argument by and large, but I do quibble with some of the details.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the nautical terms for a ship that sails well in all wind directions.

idioms.example: We had no map or GPS. We got here by dead reckoning.
We’ll get the project done by hook or by crook.
We escaped the fire by the skin of our teeth.
I don’t think Andy has the nerve to jump, so I’m calling his bluff.
idioms.origin: Alludes to poker, where one player may believe another is bluffing and call for the hands to be shown.

idioms.example: Andy’s been seriously neglecting his work recently, so his manager called him on the carpet.
We’re all avoiding the real issue here. Can we just call a spade a spade and get on with finding a solution?
The restaurant’s closed, so I’m calling an audible on our dinner date.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice in American football of changing the intended play with an audible signal from the quarterback at the line of scrimmage.

idioms.example: Andy’s calling the shots around here now. She just got promoted to director.
idioms.origin: Alludes to billiards, where in some games one must call or predict one’s shots for them to count. [confirm]

idioms.example: That first little request is the camel’s nose in the tent. You’re just opening yourself up for more.
You’ve exposed a real can of worms with your inquiries.
Melting ice caps are the canary in the coal mine on climate change.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the mining practice of using canaries in coal mines to indicate by dying the presence of dangerous gases.

idioms.keywords: cannot (or can’t) hold a candle to (one)

idioms.example: The cards are stacked against Andy getting the job. He doesn’t know the right people.
idioms.origin: Alludes to poker and other card games, where advantage can be gained by prearranging the deck.

idioms.example: The party leaders are on a campaign of carpet bombing. They’re not letting any transgression go unpunished.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the military practice of indiscriminate rather than focused bombing of an enemy.

idioms.example: He’s always willing to carry the professor’s water in hopes of improving his standing.

idioms.paraphrase: hopie for a romantic relationship with (one)
idioms.example: Andy’s been carrying a torch for him ever since they met.

idioms.paraphrase: continue with the job at hand
idioms.origin: keep carrying the sails on
Probably alludes to the appearance of the spokes during the turning of a wooden cart wheel.

idioms.example: After their last success, they’ve been given carte blanche on their next project.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the card game Piquet.

idioms.example: I’m tired of this job. It’s time for me to cash in my chips.
Sorry, no credit cards and no checks. We accept cash on the barrel head only.
His speech was so bad that the auditorium was full of cat calls.
Don’t you have anything to say about this? Has the cat got your tongue??
Andy’s gotten a significant inheritance. She’s sitting in the catbird seat now.
Andy got caught dead to rights cheating on his diet.
idioms.comment: Often implies an illegal or forbidden act.

idioms.example: Andy got caught red-handed cheating on his diet.
idioms.comment: Often implies an illegal or forbidden act.

idioms.keywords: catch (one) with (one’s) hand in the cookie jar

idioms.example: You can’t get hired without experience, but you need experience to get hired. It’s a real Catch 22.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the paradoxical situation posed in Joseph Heller’s book Catch 22: A pilot claiming insanity in the hopes of being dismissed from flying dangerous missions demonstrates his own sanity by making the claim and therefore must continue flying.

idioms.example: It seemed like the refs were against us. We simply could not catch a break.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to surfing, where a break is an obstacle in the sea that creates breaking, surfable waves.

idioms.example: Andy has been a really good addition to the team. We definitely caught a break when we hired her.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to surfing, where a break is an obstacle in the sea that creates breaking, surfable waves.

idioms.paraphrase: make the best of the situation
idioms.example: There’s not much to eat here. It’s catch as catch can for dinner.

idioms.origin: surfing

idioms.example: He was a perfect cowboy, straight out of central casting.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the department of a movie studio that casts actors to fill roles requiring stereotypical characters.

idioms.example: That’s an important decision. I think we need to send it up the chain of command.
Once Andy decided to go, there was a chain reaction of everyone else leaving one by one.
idioms.origin: Alludes to nuclear fission, where the reaction starts small but grows in a cascading fashion.

idioms.example: Brock and Andy are chalk and cheese; they don’t get along at all.
Andy’s changed his tune since he found out she’s interested in him.
Our current approach obviously isn’t working. It’s time to change gears.
We’ve covered that subject well enough. I’d like to change gears now.
They want to assign us a new manager in the middle of a big project? Why are we changing horses in midstream?
idioms.origin: Alludes to a speech by Abraham Lincoln during his1864 re-election in which he said it is "not best to swap horses when crossing streams".

idioms.paraphrase: replacing of old personnel with newer
idioms.example: We’ve had a thorough changing of the guard here. Most of the original founders have retired and been replaced by younger people.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the sometimes elaborate protocols of changing the guards on duty at significant sites such as Buckingham Palace.

idioms.example: Andy read the rules to us chapter and verse.
There was no need to mention Carey’s recent breakup. That was just a cheap shot.
He cherry-picked his questions to make himself look good.
Oh, we’re just chewing the fat. There’s nothing important going on here.
They offered the workers a raise, but it was chicken feed.

idioms.paraphrase: a situation in which two things are interdependent for their existence
idioms.example: It’s a bit of a chicken-and-egg problem, isn’t it? We can’t get started without some seed money, but we can get any money without showing some progress.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the paradoxical question "Which came first — the chicken or the egg?"

idioms.example: Andy’s always had a chip on his shoulder about coming from a humble background.
The coach gave them a good locker-room talk and now they’re chomping at the bit.
A poor girl from Sudan becomes a top fashion designer — what a Cinderella story!
idioms.comment: Implies that the successful person started from a low station in life.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the widely told folk tale Cinderella.

idioms.example: With no new products for years and sales falling, they’re circling the drain.
The lecturers are circling the wagons for a fight against the administration.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice in the United States of circling the wagons of a wagon train in the evening for defensive purposes.

idioms.example: He thought he was good at poker, but Andy cleaned his clock.
That kitchen is clean as a whistle.
I took my car in for a check-up and it got a clean bill of health.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to the historical practice of inspecting a ship newly arrived in a port to ensure that it’s not carrying contagious diseases.

idioms.example: They divorced amicably about a year ago. It was a clean break.
idioms.comment: Implies a dissociation with no lingering complications.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to the practice in boxing of the referee making boxers in a clutch completely separate from each other before renewing the fight..

idioms.example: The last venture failed so badly that they decided to clean house and start over.

idioms.origin: nautical?

idioms.example: I have a group of clients coming in this week, so I need to clear the decks.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice on warships of removing extraneous objects from the decks before a battle.

idioms.example: She wants this to be a complete surprise, so she’s keeping her plans very cloak-and-dagger.
His effort was close but no cigar.
idioms.comment: Used jokingly.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to the tradition of a father giving out cigars on the birth of a child.

idioms.example: That car swerved out of the way just in time. What a close call!
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the official in a sporting contest making a call in a tight situation.

idioms.example: That car swerved out of the way just in time. That was a close shave!

idioms.keywords: close the barn door after the horse has left the barn
idioms.paraphrase: try too late to prevent the damage
idioms.example: You can’t untell her secret. You’re trying to close the barn door after the horse has left the barn.
It looks like the coast is clear. All the teachers are gone.
Andy gave the sergeant a real cock and bull story and he bought it!
In Congress, political favors are the coin of the realm. That’s how things get done.
Andy’s horse was a heavy favorite, but he came a cropper in the homestretch.
Oh, come off it. You’e just pretending to believe that story.
It’s no secret among his friends that Andy comes from a very poor background, but he has yet to come out of the closet.
idioms.comment: Implies a secret perceived to be shameful.

idioms.example: Andy came out swinging in the debate.
idioms.origin: Alludes to boxing, where one boxer might come out aggressively at the beginning of a round.

idioms.example: Andy’s boss brought her in for a little come-to-Jesus meeting, so she’s no longer fighting the project.
idioms.comment: Implies a lecture from someone of indisputable authority.

idioms.example: We have volunteers coming out of the woodwork here. What will we do with all of them?
idioms.origin: insect infestation?

idioms.example: OK, team, I think we have all the data we need. Let’s connect the dots.
Don’t let anyone tell you that academia is not a contact sport.
He’s cooked the books for years so that he could skim a little of the profit for his family.
idioms.comment: Implies alterations intended to create an inaccurately rosy picture.

idioms.example: Andy thinks she’s cornered the market on good ideas.
Don’t count your chickens yet. There are still some uncounted votes.
idioms.comment: Sometimes followed by "before they’re hatched".

idioms.example: This proposal will be reviewed very carefully, so we need to make sure we cover all the bases.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to baseball, where a baserunner must touch every base; also fielders must sometimes protect or cover every base..

idioms.example: Andy’s cracking the whip. She really wants her students to win this competition.
There are so many strong candidates that it’s a total crap shoot as to who will win.
Critical mass for a good poker game is at least four people.
idioms.origin: Alludes to nuclear fission, where a certain minimal amount of radioactive material is necessary to initiate the reaction.

idioms.example: Andy doesn’t really care about the refugees. Those are crocodile tears.
Andy has crossed his Rubicon. He publicly declared his candidacy today.
idioms.comment: Often implies that a commitment is also risky.

idioms.example: Andy and I never agree on anything. We seem to cross swords in every meeting.

idioms.keywords: cross that bridge when (one) gets to it
idioms.paraphrase: deal with something when it arises
idioms.example: We don’t know what we’ll find, so we’ll just cross that bridge when we get to it.
Don’t worry. Taking care of the in-laws will be my cross to bear.
idioms.comment: Implies an undesirable responsibility. Often used facetiously.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the Christian tradition that Jesus was forced to carry the cross on which he was crucified.

idioms.example: Continuing to complain about that accident is just crying over spilled milk.
idioms.origin: old saying

idioms.example: Andy’s just crying wolf again. To him, every cloud means a thunderstorm is coming.
idioms.origin: Alludes to Aesop’s fable The Boy Who Cried Wolf.

idioms.example: Spending a whole evening playing cards is just not my cup of tea.
idioms.comment: Usually used in the negative.

idioms.example: Andy’s hoping for a promotion, so he’s doing everything he can to curry favor with the boss.
idioms.comment: Implies approval gained by obsequious behavior.

idioms.example: Andy is expecting a curtain call for her hard work on this project.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice in theater of performers returning to a curtained stage after the performance to have the curtain raised for further applause.

idioms.example: Andy gave me a small project to cut my teeth on.
Andy loves to dance and she can really cut a rug.
There’s no mystery to maintaining a bicycle. It’s pretty cut and dried.
He’s pretending to be brave, but in the end I think he’ll cut and run.
idioms.comment: Implies a hasty,  unseemly retreat.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice of a sailing ship cutting its anchor rope so as to make a quick getaway.

idioms.example: On first acquaintance she and Andy seem very different, but they’re really cut from the same cloth.
I really like the cut of his jib. I think he’ll do a good job for us.
idioms.comment: archaic

idioms.example: It’s time to cut the cord and let you work on your own.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice of cutting the umbilical cord when a child is born.

idioms.example: Andy couldn’t cut the mustard, so she resigned.
Please, we’ve heard enough extraneous detail. Can we cut to the chase?
Andy’s previous experience cuts no ice with the new coach. He needs to see him perform.
My dance card is full this week. Can we meet next week instead?
The Wildcats were definitely the dark horse of the tournament and they’ve surprised everyone.

idioms.paraphrase: the resting place of those who die at sea

idioms.example: Brock doesn’t know it yet, but he’s a dead duck. The other players are teaming up against him.
That proposal is dead in the water. Everything about it is wrong.
Given who proposed it, that idea was dead on arrival.
A friend of mine gets double-takes all the time because he’s a dead ringer for Willie Nelson.

idioms.keywords: deader than (or as dead as) a dormouse (or doornail)
idioms.example: That battery hasn’t a spark of life. It’s deader than a dormouse.
Insurance companies are assumed to have deep pockets, so they’re frequent targets for law suits.
Those old skis weren’t even worth giving away. I deep-sixed them.
idioms.origin: six fathoms deep

idioms.example: If you go ahead with that plan, there will be the devil to pay.
idioms.comment: The historically complete phrase, no longer used, includes "and no pitch hot".
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical nautical practice of sealing, or paying, with tar or pitch the seam, known as the devil, where the deck meets the sides of a ship.

idioms.example: Andy aced every test and did not break a sweat.

idioms.origin: metal casting?

idioms.example: Andy’s proposition died on the vine because he couldn’t get any backers.

idioms.origin: military – foxholes, trenches

idioms.example: Realtors are a dime a dozen around here. You can hardly escape them.

idioms.origin: small toll or personals bag

idioms.example: Andy needs to be there on Monday, but there are no flights before late Sunday afternoon. You can do the math.
idioms.comment: Implies a conclusion that is obvious from the evidence.

idioms.example: Andy really dodged a bullet when they discovered that his tumor was benign.
It’s just a dog and pony show to grab their attention. Then we can show them what the product can really do.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the tradition of trained animals acts being included in Vaudeville shows.

idioms.example: After hearing all the alternatives Andy opted for door number two.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the TV game show Let’s Make a Deal where contestants chose one of three doors to receive as a prize whatever was behind it.
idioms.comment: The number is almost always 1, 2, or 3.

idioms.example: We’ve been double crossed. Andy said he’d cooperate with us but instead he took his idea to our competitor.
Andy’s not only refusing to apologize, she’s doubling down on her insults.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the card game blackjack or 21 where one can play two hands at once if initially dealt a pair.

idioms.paraphrase: situation with both pros and cons
idioms.example: Andy’s presence is a double-edged sword, isn’t it? He’s quite smart and has good ideas, but he’s difficult to work with.
They didn’t manage their wealth intelligently, so they’re a bit down at the heels.
idioms.comment: Implies that the impoverished was or were previously well off.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the fact that old, well-used shoes will get worn down at the heels.

idioms.example: Andy’s down for the count. She’s exhausted and already in bed.
idioms.origin: Alludes to boxing (or wrestling), where one competitor loses by being unable to rise (or escape) for a count of 10 (or 3).

idioms.example: OK, team, we’ve spent too much time on trivialities. It’s time to get down to brass tacks.
The election went down to the wire. It was determined by the last few hundred votes.
idioms.origin: Alludes to horse or foot racing, where the winner is the first to reach a wire, tape, or similar line suspended across the finish line.

idioms.example: Andy wanted a dress rehearsal of her interview, so we grilled her with lots of hard questions.
idioms.origin: Alludes to theater, where the final rehearsal before opening is performed in full dress.

idioms.example: It was prom night and the kids were all dressed to the nines.
Andy clearly drank the Kool-Aid. She’s mindlessly parroting the cult’s dogma.
We can trust Andy with our secret. He won’t drop a dime on us.
I confess that I dropped the ball on that assignment.
That experiment was a dry hole. We got absolutely no useful results from it.
idioms.origin: Alludes to drilling wells in search of oil or water, where a dry well is obviously a failure.

idioms.example: Andy wanted a dry run of her interview, so we grilled her with lots of hard questions.
Andy grew up in Texas so she’s a dyed-in-the-wool Cowboys fan.
idioms.origin: Alludes to dyeing wool, where dyeing the wool before spinning results in more lasting color.

idioms.example: Andy’s earned his stripes and is definitely ready for more responsibility.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the military, where stripes are in some situations an indication of rank.

idioms.example: He thought he was good at poker, but Andy ate his lunch.
Andy had to eat crow after his solution proved unworkable.
idioms.comment: Implies that one strongly advocated for the error.

idioms.example: Andy had to eat humble pie after his solution proved unworkable.
idioms.comment: Implies that one strongly advocated for the error.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the word "umbles" meaning  the entrails of an animal, usually considered inferior food.

idioms.example: Andy’s never satisfied; she’s always looking for El Dorado.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the mythical city of El Dorado that was made of gold.

idioms.comment: usually physical, as in scrubbing dishes

idioms.example: Everyone’s excited about Carey’s great idea, but the elephant in the room is that there’s no budget for it.
I don’t have much time. Just give me the elevator pitch.
Why does the customer always come up with these requests at the eleventh hour?
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the prototypical work day running from 6am to 6pm, where anything happening in the eleventh hour was very late in the day.

idioms.paraphrase: the person’s stature is all pretense
idioms.example: Andy always presents himself as a great CEO, but we all know that the emperor has no clothes.
idioms.origin: Alludes to The Emperor’s New Clothes, a tale by Hans Christian Andersen.

idioms.example: They’ve agreed on all the major points, and now the negotiations are in the end game.
idioms.origin: Alludes to chess, where the game is considered to proceed in three phases: opening, mid-game, and end game.

idioms.example: Andy is at the end of her tether with all these niggling criticisms.
We’ve worked together for a long time, Andy, but I think we’re at the end of the line.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to railroads, where a train’s final destination is the end of the line.

idioms.example: We’ve had so many problems with the project, but I think we’re going to end on a high note.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the stereotypical opera performance, which ends on a forceful prolonged high note.

idioms.example: Andy’s presentation was a real face plant.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to a hard fall taken in skiing, skateboarding, or similar sports; or possibly alludes to falling as a facet of physical comedy.

idioms.example: I got caught, so it looks like I have to go face the music.
We need to do this fair and square so no one feels shortchanged.
Andy didn’t do well in the tryouts, but he wasn’t given a fair shake.
He always seems to be the fall guy when his buddies cause trouble.
idioms.origin: Alludes to Albert Fall, US Secretary of the Interior convicted in the Teapot Dome scandal of receiving a bribe when the giver of the same bribe was acquitted.

idioms.example: Andy had to fall on her sword, because her boss certainly wasn’t going to take the blame.
idioms.comment: Implies sacrificing oneself to protect one’s superior. This can only be said of a person falling on his or her own sword. No one can be said to fall on someone else’s sword.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to the historical Japanese Samurai practice of ritual suicide intended to redeem one’s honor and performed by disemboweling oneself with a sword.

idioms.example: We’ve been really busy around here and I’m afraid your application just fell through the cracks.
Andy’s says she’ll ski right down this slope, but those sound like famous last words.
Fast forward six weeks, and Andy was suddenly less enamored with her new boyfriend.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to the capability of rapidly moving forward in video or audio recordings.

idioms.example: Andy was certainly fast out of the gate on her assignment.
That Andy did such a good job is a feather in her cap.
When they started giving away all the used computer equipment, the engineers had an absolute feeding frenzy.
Andy got a B on his test! He has feet of clay after all.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the Biblical book of Daniel, where feet of clay are interpreted to indicate weakness.

idioms.example: The company is falling apart, but he’s just fiddling while Rome burns.
idioms.comment: Implies attending to trivialities while ignoring the crisis.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the legend that Nero, an emperor of the Roman Empire, was playing a fiddle while the city of Rome burned.

idioms.example: The reporters are having a field day picking apart his evasive answers.
idioms.origin: nautical, day for cleaning up

idioms.example: I’s a fielder’s choice for me, so you choose where we eat.
idioms.origin: Alludes to baseball, where a fielder sometimes has a choice between two equal opportunities to get an out.
Alludes to the Biblical story of the Garden of Eden, where Adam and Eve were created naked but are frequently depicted in art with a fig leaf covering their genitals.

idioms.example: If they think a purely emotional appeal will work, we’ll just have to fight fire with fire.
I think this place will fill the bill nicely.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to a concert or similar performance where several acts or pieces are necessary to create a full schedule of entertainment.
movies? sports?

idioms.example: She’s gone. Flunking that course was the final nail in her coffin.
This security systems test is annoying and time-consuming, but it’s a necessary fire drill.
idioms.comment: Can imply that the routine is also pointless.

idioms.example: This is an important conference, so we’re sending our first string.
idioms.origin: Possibly originally alludes to a line of pack horses or mules connected one to the next by ropes; now commonly used to refer to starting players on sports teams.

idioms.example: This is an important conference, so we’re sending our first team.
idioms.origin: Alludes to sports teams, where the best players make up the first team.

idioms.example: Yes, I was pretty sick last week, but I’m fit as a fiddle now.
Andy is fit to be tied after seeing those results.
They’re not that good a team. The upset was just a flash in the pan.
idioms.comment: Implies an achievement unsupported by enduring ability and unlikely to be repeated.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical flintlock guns, which sometimes misfired with the powder in the pan igniting without igniting the charge in the barrel that propelled the ball.

idioms.example: Neither of us have run this machine before. We’re flying blind here.
idioms.origin: Alludes to flying aircraft, where flying at night or in bad weather could mean flying with no visibility.

idioms.keywords: fly by the seat of (one’s) pants
idioms.example: No, I didn’t look at the instructions. I’m flying by the seat of my pants.
idioms.comment: Always used in reference to the same person performing the action. One cannot fly by the seat of someone else’s pants.

idioms.example: Andy is prone to fly off the handle at the least perception of disrespect.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the possibility of the head flying off the handle when a poorly made axe is swung, thereby endangering anyone around.

idioms.example: Our kids have all graduated and flown the coop.
idioms.comment: Often implies leaving home.

idioms.keywords: fly to close to the sun

idioms.example: The conference wasn’t going well for them, so they folded their tents and went home early.
Andy’s salmon order sounds good, so I think I’ll follow suit.
idioms.origin: Alludes to some card games, where a player may be required to play a card of the same suit that was previously played.

idioms.example: Convincing Andy to change his mind is a fool’s errand.
Who’s footing the bill for all your home improvements?
Oh, let’s humor her just for ducks.
That notion is simply for the birds.
Andy broke up with her boyfriend last week, so she’s a free agent.
idioms.origin: Alludes to professional sports, where a player whose contract has ended is free to pursue other options.

idioms.example: Andy’s manager gave him free rein on this project.
idioms.origin: Alludes to horseback riding, where giving the horse a loose, or free, rein allows it to choose its own pace.

idioms.example: Andy fell victim to friendly fire when her colleague unintentionally undercut her proposal.
You can argue from now ’til kingdom come and you won’t change her mind.
We cleaned the cabin from stem to stern.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to the nautical terms "stem" and "stern" for the front and back ends of a boat.

idioms.example: This is solid information, straight from the horse’s mouth.
Nurses are definitely on the front lines in our health care system.
idioms.origin: Alludes to military battles, where the soldiers closest to the enemy — in front — are in the fiercest conflict and greatest danger.

idioms.example: We so enjoyed the work that the award was just frosting on the cake.
We’ve got the resources we need. Now it’s full steam ahead on our project.
They were anxious to get done, so they went at it full tilt.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to the medieval sport of jousting, or tilting, in which two knights rode at each other at full speed in an attempt to unhorse each other with lances.

idioms.example: We need to get started with this effort. So what’s our game plan?
idioms.origin: Alludes to sports, where a well-prepared team enters a game with a plan to counter the opponent’s strengths and take advantage of its weaknesses.

idioms.keywords: get (or have) (one’s) ducks in a row
idioms.example: She’s got her ducks in a row and feels completely ready for the meeting.
That gaff at dinner certainly left egg on Andy’s face.
Your comment about Andy’s brother really got her goat.
Andy’s and hard worker and willing to get her hands dirty.
Andy gets his kicks by skiing recklessly, so I stay away from him.

idioms.origin: hockey

idioms.example: Your comment about her brother really got a rise out of Andy.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to fishing, where a fish attracted to bait is said to rise to it.

idioms.paraphrase: don’t give up after a setback
idioms.origin: riding

idioms.example: You’re just getting colder with this line of questioning.
Andy was going to ask her out, but he got cold feet.
That’s enough talk about this hike! Let’s get cranking.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to the method of starting early cars by using a handle in front to crank the engine until ignition.

idioms.example: I spoke up now because I was afraid I’d get lost in the shuffle.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to card games, where the deck is often shuffled to randomize the order of the cards.

idioms.keywords: get on (one’s) soapbox (or be on (one’s) soapbox)
idioms.example: Andy always gets on his soapbox when politics enters the conversation.
idioms.comment: Implies monopolizing conversation.

idioms.example: Uh-oh, here comes the hall monitor. We better get out of Dodge.
idioms.comment: Implies leaving before one’s ill deeds are discovered.

idioms.keywords: get out of jail free card

idioms.example: Andy didn’t like the new process at first, but now he’s got religion.
Andy got the green light on her thesis proposal.
Gee, everyone’s wearing a tie but me. Guess I didn’t get the memo.
idioms.comment: Usually used informally.

idioms.example: Did your project idea even get to first base?
idioms.comment: Often implies progress of a romantic or sexual nature.

idioms.example: Did your project idea get any traction?
It always takes a while for anyone to get up to speed on this new technology.
I realize I’m completely guessing here, but am I even getting warm?
The decorations are perfect. Adding any more would just be gilding the lily.
idioms.origin: Alludes to Shakespeare’s metaphor in the play King John: "To gild refined gold, to paint the lily ... is wasteful and ridiculous excess".

idioms.keywords: give (one) the old heave-ho (or heave ho)
idioms.example: They gave the coach the old heave-ho after three unsuccessful seasons.
idioms.comment: Often used to indicate firing someone.

idioms.example: Those kids tried to follow us, but we went out the side door and gave them the slip.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the nautical practice of completely releasing, or slipping, the anchor cable so as to escape quickly.

idioms.example: This engine has given us good service for years, but I think it has given up the ghost.
idioms.comment: Used informally and jokingly.

idioms.example: Students here are usually given a bye on their first offense if it’s not too serious.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to sports tournaments, where sometimes a team may not have to compete in the first round, thus getting a bye.

idioms.example: When those two lawyers meet in court, the gloves are always off.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to hockey, where players remove their gloves for a serious fight.

idioms.example: The team isn’t working well together and this project is rapidly going south.
Andy decided that any amount of drinking was not healthy for her, so she went cold turkey.

idioms.keywords: go at it hammer and tongs
idioms.example: They were both so angry that they went at it hammer and tongs.
Andy’s little startup has gone belly up after just six months.
That feature went by the board. We didn’t think it was important or useful.
idioms.origin: Alludes to ships and other vessels, where the phrase refers to something going overboard.

idioms.example: Andy is seen as responsible for the project’s failure, so he’s going down with the ship.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the nautical tradition that a captain remains on a sinking ship.

idioms.example: They’re not going to play for a tie. They need to win so they’re going for broke.
Andy won’t settle for second best. He’s going for the gold.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to the Olympic Games, where a gold medal is the reward for winning an event.

idioms.example: The students love this experiment, so they’re really going great guns on it.
idioms.origin: RH Dana, p205

idioms.example: Andy’s gone off the deep end. He thinks we can do this climb in two hours!
We’ve lost sight of our goals and this project has really gone off the rails.
idioms.origin: Alludes to a train wreck happening when a train goes off its rails.

idioms.example: Andy’s parents went absolutely postal when they discovered he was skipping his classes.
idioms.origin: Alludes to a series of shootings by unhinged individuals that occurred several decades ago in the US Postal Service.

idioms.example: If Andy believes you’re doing your best, she’ll go to bat for you.
No one has seen Andy for weeks. He seems to have gone to ground.

idioms.keywords: go to hell in a handbasket
idioms.paraphrase: be on the path to disaster
idioms.example: This company has no direction and I think it’s going to hell in a handbasket.
After his divorce, Andy has let himself go to seed.
This company has no direction and I think it’s going to the dogs.
If Andy believes in you, she’ll go to the mat for you.
idioms.origin: Alludes to wrestling, where going to the mat represents real struggle.

idioms.example: The students love this experiment, so they’re really going to town on it.
Some good Samaritan found her wallet and returned it without taking anything.
idioms.comment: Usually implies that the bystander is a stranger.

idioms.example: Andy is focused and doing well. I think she’ll grab the brass ring.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice of suspending brass rings just within the reach of carousel riders that, when grabbed, resulted in a prize.

idioms.example: I have no idea what the answer is. I’m just grasping at straws.
We won’t see much of Andy this summer. She’s working the graveyard shift.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the perhaps apocryphal tradition of tending a grave overnight to ensure that interred person was actually dead.

idioms.example: Even though it’s illegal, you’re expected to grease people’s palms when doing business in many foreign countries.
The last team greased the skids for us, so completing this job should be easy.
Andy thinks his idea will be the greatest thing since sliced bread.
idioms.comment: Often used facetiously.

idioms.example: The central square is ground zero for the protest, so the police are hanging out there.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to testing of bombs, where the phrase refers to the point of impact and explosion.

idioms.example: She’s trying a new teaching approach this term, so we get to be her guinea pigs.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the perhaps apocryphal notion that scientific experiments are often performed on guinea pigs.

idioms.example: Andy got a hall pass from his wife, so he’s going with us this weekend.
Andy’s accumulated so many points that he’s got a hammer lock on the prize.
She’s vain and sensitive. You’d better handle her with kid gloves.
Andy won that debate hands down.
I was hoping to work here longer, but I can see the handwriting on the wall.
idioms.comment: Often implies that the evidence is also intangible.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the Biblical story in the Daniel of handwriting that magically appeared on a wall foretelling the downfall of a Babylonian king.

idioms.example: He was just doing his job, but when the problems arose the company hung him out to dry.

idioms.origin: old gun not firing

idioms.example: It’s important that Andy get this job. His family’s future hangs in the balance.
I’m warm, dry, and well fed now, so I’m happy as a clam.
I’ve been sick all week, so I’m not a very happy camper.
I’m exhausted from meetings all day. Is it happy hour yet?
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to a short relaxation period for all crew possible on historic sailing vessels. Usually late afternoons, a time to unwind after work

idioms.paraphrase: a performance that sets a high standard
idioms.example: Andy is a hard act to follow, but I think you’ll find my presentation interesting also.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to vaudeville, which typically had numerous acts within the same show.

idioms.example: That professor’s a real hard ass, but his students learn a lot and actually enjoy his class.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to historical American cavalry general George Custer, who was labeled "Hard Ass" by his troops for his stamina in the saddle.

idioms.example: It’s hard to know for sure, but this joke has Andy’s fingerprints all over it.
They’ve rejected every one of his arguments, so now they have him up a tree.
Climate change is an impending disaster, but too many people have their heads in the sand.
idioms.origin: Alludes to ostriches, which are mistakenly thought to bury their heads in sand thinking they have thereby escaped danger.

idioms.example: This cabin needs so many repairs. We’ve got our work cut out for us.
idioms.comment: Implies challenging work.

idioms.origin: Paladin

idioms.example: Some politicians seem to have nine lives. They say stupid things yet keep getting re-elected.
Andy didn’t want to take that project on, but now she has the bit between her teeth.

idioms.paraphrase: end up in the better position
idioms.example: Andy used to beat me regularly, but I’ve been secretly practicing, so I think I’ll have the last laugh.
idioms.comment: Often implies ending up in the better position unexpectedly.

idioms.keywords: head them up and move them out
idioms.example: These kids should be on the bus by now. Let’s head ‘em up and move ‘em out.
idioms.comment: Usually used informally as "head ‘em up, move ‘em out".
idioms.origin: Alludes to herding cattle in the American West.

idioms.example: I got a heads up from Andy about the quiz today or I would have been completely unprepared.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to baseball, where a player must look up to see a fly ball.

idioms.example: Heads will roll after that catastrophic demo cost us the sale.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice of decapitating individuals convicted of crimes against the king, the queen, or the state.

idioms.example: I heard through the grape vine that he and Andy are seeing each other now.
This is a very important case, so the firm is bringing in the heavy artillery on this one.
Andy is one of their heavy hitters. They only bring her in for the most important negotiations.
I can’t take credit for this. Andy did all the heavy lifting.
She’s hell on wheels. She makes an impression wherever she goes.
idioms.comment: Can imply that the notoriety is not necessarily for bad actions.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice of providing entertainment for rail workers in the American west with a saloon and brothel on wheels, referred to as "Hell on Wheels".

idioms.paraphrase: attempt to impose order on chaos
idioms.example: Getting a bunch of ten-year-old boys to focus on a group project is like herding cats.
She tried every avenue of appeal that the school offers. All were denied, so now she’s high and dry.
idioms.origin: Alludes to a boat that has run aground at high tide that later is entirely out of the water.

idioms.example: They set a very high bar for admittance to the club.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to high-jumping in track and field, where a higher bar makes the jump harder.

idioms.example: This is high noon for the team. They must win this game or go home.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the perhaps apocryphal tradition that gunfights in the American west were held at high noon, as memorialized in the movie High Noon.

idioms.example: Andy got a big end-of-year bonus, so he’s living high on the hog for a while.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the fact that the preferable meat comes from higher on the hog.

idioms.example: Andy’s higher on the food chain than I am, so she ultimately sets my priorities.
I don’t patronize them. Their prices are highway robbery.
Andy’s a hired gun. She travels around the country giving expert medical testimony.

idioms.origin: boxing

idioms.example: We’ve hit paydirt! We finally found a source for the parts we need.
idioms.origin: Alludes to prospecting, where the phrase refers to ground rich in ore or gems.

idioms.keywords: hit the cover off the ball

idioms.example: Andy’s had previous experience with this technology, so she can hit the ground running.
We’ve hit the jackpot! We finally found a source for the parts we need.
idioms.origin: Alludes to gambling, where the phrase refers to significant winnings.

idioms.example: I think there’s a bunch of hocus pocus going on with the demo.
idioms.origin: Possibly a corruption of the Latin phrase "hoc est corpus meum", meaning "this is my body", used in Roman Catholic liturgy.

idioms.example: Andy’s been arguing that they must stick to the budget, but now that he’s got a big project in mind, he’s being hoist by his own petard.
The execs are holding Andy’s feet to the fire until she changes her mind.
idioms.origin: Alludes to a medieval form of torture.

idioms.example: We’ve got no chance here. Andy holds all the cards.
idioms.origin: Alludes to card games where holding a hand full of strong cards is an advantage.

idioms.example: They’ve tried very hard to get Andy’s project derailed, but so far she’s holding serve.
idioms.origin: Alludes to tennis, where to hold serve is to win the game in which one is serving, or volleyball, where a team wins a point on which it served and thus retains the serve.

idioms.example: Can you hold the fort while I’m away?
idioms.comment: Often used lightly.

idioms.example: Hold your horses, Andy. We’ve still got a lot of planning to do.
A cure for cancer is the Holy Grail of medical research.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the Christian legend that the cup, or grail, that Jesus used during the Last Supper is still to be found somewhere in the world. Traditionally, the Holy Grail was the object of quests by medieval knights.

idioms.example: Now that testing is done, this effort is in the home stretch.
idioms.origin: Alludes to horse racing, where the phrase refers to the final straight length of track before the finish line.

idioms.example: Andy’s on the last chapter of her thesis and she’s like a horse headed for the barn.
I’m happy to help, but if you’re asking me to work over the weekend that’s a horse of a different color.
This problem required nothing more than good old horse sense.
There was a big hue and cry after the news broke, but it died out soon enough.
idioms.comment: Derived from the historical French phrase "hu e cri" meaning "outcry and cry".
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical obligation to raise an outcry in pursuit of a criminal.

idioms.keywords: I have a bridge to sell you
idioms.example: If you think that big corporations have your best interest in mind, I have a bridge to sell you.
Andy’s off in his ivory tower, dreaming of a post-capitalism world.
idioms.comment: Often used pejoratively.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to a graduate research institution at Princeton that was partially sponsored by the founder of the company that manufactured Ivory Soap. However, there are earlier uses of the phrase in the Bible (Solomon 7:4) and in the French poem of 1837 Pensées d’Août, à M. Villemain.

idioms.example: I can’t compete with those guys. They’re in a different league.
The lobbyists are in a full court press to get this bill defeated.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the style of defense that covers the whole court in basketball.

idioms.paraphrase: at a distinctly high level of competence
idioms.example: I’m good at what I do, but Andy is in a league of her own.

idioms.paraphrase: not functioning up to (one’s) usual standard
idioms.example: Andy’s in a real slump. He hasn’t won a match in weeks.
She has been in bed with Andy all along. They were just pretending to disagree.
She and Andy have been in cahoots all along. They were just pretending to disagree.
Andy says she’s in fighting trim and ready for this trial.
idioms.comment: Implies preparation for a test or conflict.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the nautical phrase referring to a ship prepared for battle.
Possibly alludes to the historical practice of hunting by hounds, where the hounds became very vocal while in pursuit of prey.

idioms.example: He thinks Andy will accept his invitation to the dance, but he’s obviously in la-la land.
He’s so hopeful about a date with Andy, but I think he’s in never-never land.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the novel "Peter Pan; or, the Boy Who Wouldn’t Grow Up, where the eternally young character Peter Pan lived in a place called Neverland.

idioms.example: I think that estimate is in the ballpark, but we need more information to be more precise.
I’m sorry to tell you this, but a trip to Europe is just not in the cards this year.
idioms.comment: Often used in the negative, as shown.

idioms.example: Andy’s perceived as vulnerable in the next election,  so she’s in the opposition’s cross hairs.
After Andy’s misbehavior over the weekend, his wife has him in the dog house.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to the small shelters for dogs frequently found in the backyards of homes.

idioms.example: Andy’s got the blueprints and the experience, so he’s definitely in the driver’s seat for now.
We can’t ease off on our efforts now — we’re in the homestretch.
They’ve won their last several games, so I think they’re in the hunt for the trophy.
Andy was really upset about something, and I just happened to be in the line of fire.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the trajectory of bullets or other ammunition being termed the "line of fire".

idioms.example: Andy’s been out too late several nights this week, so her parents have her in the penalty box. We won’t see her tonight.
idioms.origin: Alludes to ice hockey, where the phrase refers to a seat where a player who has committed a foul must spend a designated time off the ice.

idioms.example: How many recruits do we have in the pipeline?
The managers don’t know how hard this work is. We’re the ones in the trenches.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the once common military practice of digging trenches to protect infantry in the front lines of battles.

idioms.example: I think Andy has the inside track on the new position. She’s a friend of the hiring manager.
idioms.origin: Alludes to racing of many kinds where having the inside line on the oval racetrack is advantageous.

idioms.keywords: it ain’t (or isn’t) over ’til the fat lady sings
idioms.paraphrase: the event isn’t over until the official end
idioms.example: This game looks lost, but you know it ain’t over ’til the fat lady sings.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to the stereotypical belief that every opera ends with the diva, stereotypically a substantial woman, singing an aria.

idioms.paraphrase: it’s a dangerous and unforgiving world
idioms.example: It’s a jungle out there and you’ve got to take care of yourself.

idioms.paraphrase: I don’t understand it at all
idioms.example: This report is greek to me. It’s way too technical.
You can ignore Andy. He just likes to jerk people’s chains.
idioms.comment: Can imply intentionally annoying teasing.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the once common practice of bear-baiting, where a bear chained to a post was set upon by dogs.

idioms.example: So many people are raving about this diet, Andy decided to jump on the bandwagon.
This group needs a jump start. How can we get them motivated?
I think you jumped the gun with that purchase. They’re coming out with a new version next month.

idioms.comment: and implausible
idioms.origin: Happy Days

idioms.example: They’re making Andy jump through all kinds of hoops before they’ll allow him to graduate.
idioms.comment: Often implies tasks that are bureaucratic in nature.

idioms.example: The jury’s still out on whether Andy is up to the challenge.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the legal practice of jury trials, where the jury retires from the courtroom to decide the outcome of a trial.
nautical

idioms.example: The investigation was just a bit of Kabuki theater, too cursory to uncover any significant details.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the extravagantly stylized form of theater historically popular in Japanese culture.

idioms.paraphrase: a pretense of a fair hearing
idioms.example: It was a kangaroo court and Andy never had a chance to defend himself.

idioms.keywords: keep (or have) an ear to the ground
idioms.example: Let’s keep an ear to the ground. There may be something to these rumors.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice among Native Americans and others in the American west of putting an ear to the ground to hear the hoofbeats of distant horsemen.

idioms.example: There are so many distractions at work that it’s hard to keep my eye on the ball.
This is just the beginning of our negotiations. We need to keep our powder dry until we reach the critical issues.
idioms.origin: Alludes to early muzzle-loading rifles, the use of which required carrying a separate stash of gunpowder that had to be kept dry.

idioms.example: Keep your nose clean this term. I don’t want to hear any bad reports.
idioms.comment: Usually used as a command.

idioms.example: This group needs a kick start. How can we get them motivated?

idioms.comment: Used informally and jokingly.

idioms.keywords: kick the can down the road
idioms.example: It’s a tough decision and they’re afraid to make a mistake,  so they’re just kicking the can down the road.
idioms.comment: Implies action delayed for someone else to handle in the future.

idioms.example: Have you had a chance to kick the tires on Andy’s latest prototype?
idioms.origin: Alludes to perhaps apocryphal belief that one should test the quality of a used car before purchase by kicking the tires and slamming the doors.

idioms.example: They’re asking a king’s ransom for a product that’s only average.
That’s Andy’s knee jerk reaction to anything smacking of socialism.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the medical practice of testing a patient’s reactions by tapping the front of the knee with a small rubber mallet to produce the usual involuntary response.

idioms.example: Andy’s hoping for a knight in shining armor, but she needs to work things out for herself.
idioms.comment: Implies that the savior is unrealistically hoped for.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to the stereotypical medieval tale in which a noble knight arrives in the end to save the princess, slay the dragon, etc.
signal by drum to stop rowing a galley

idioms.example: Everyone else has failed to fix this, but sure, knock yourself out.
idioms.comment: Implies that you don’t know what you’re getting into.

idioms.example: You know the drill when Andy’s upset, right? We all have to respond like this is a real crisis.
I know you know the ropes here. I don’t have to explain how we do things.
idioms.origin: Alludes to having to learn the uses of the many ropes on a sailing vessel.

idioms.keywords: know where the bodies are buried
idioms.example: Andy’s been in the club for years and she knows where the bodies are buried.
They’ve already hired a new coach, so Andy’s a lame duck — no one will listen to her.
idioms.comment: Occurs when someone has been supplanted but is still in position.

idioms.example: Andy made a last ditch effort to save her position here, but she’s made too many mistakes.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the military practice of digging successive trenches to protect infantry, where the rearmost trench or ditch is the final defense.

idioms.example: This game is Andy’s last hurrah. She graduates this year.
This is the last lap. We’re very close to our fundraising goal.
idioms.origin: Alludes to racing of many kinds requiring multiple laps around a course.

idioms.example: Andy has stayed out too late too often, and Saturday was the last straw for his parents.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the fable about loading a camel with one straw at a time until the addition of one single straw broke the camel’s back.

idioms.example: They asked what he wanted, but they were quite surprised by the laundry list he gave them.

idioms.keywords: lay (or put) (one’s) cards on the table
idioms.example: Being coy hasn’t gotten us anywhere in these negotiations. It’s time for us all to lay our cards on the table.
idioms.origin: Alludes to various card games where competitors lay their cards out to determine who wins.

idioms.keywords: lay (or put) it all on the line
idioms.example: Andy’s very confident of her company’s success, so she’s going to lay it all on the line.
idioms.origin: craps?

idioms.example: We’re all ready to work but aren’t sure what to do. We need someone to lead the charge.
No team is a lead-pipe cinch to win in this league. Any team could win on any day.
Don’t count on Andy for much help yet. He’s still learning the ropes around here.
Looks like the kids left their calling card. There are dirty dishes in the sink.
idioms.comment: Can imply unwelcome evidence.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice in high society of leaving a personal card to indicate that one visited when the intended recipient of the visit was absent.

idioms.example: He promised to help with Andy’s project, but he went on vacation instead and left her in the lurch.
idioms.origin: Alludes to cribbage, where "lurch" refers to a decisive defeat in which one wins a game by more than double the opponent’s score.

idioms.example: Andy’s previous experience definitely gives him a leg up in this competition.
The exams were tough, but they’re over now and the students are ready to let off some steam.
He has a good record, so the sergeant let him off the hook with just a reprimand this time.
The engine has been cleaned, tuned, and refueled. You can let her rip.

idioms.keywords: let the cat out of the bag
idioms.example: Someone let the cat out of the bag. Andy already knew about the surprise party.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the possibly apocryphal tale of selling a pig in a bag at a medieval market, where one could cheat by replacing the pig with a cat.

idioms.keywords: let the chips fall where they may
idioms.example: He’s ready to tell the truth and let the chips fall where they may.
No one wants to vote on this bill before the election, so they’re just going to let the clock run out on the session.
idioms.origin: Alludes to timed games in sports (e.g. American football), where the leading competitor can sometimes win by stalling until the clock runs out.

idioms.keywords: let the genie out of the bottle
idioms.example: Once you teach them to ski, you’ve let the genie out of the bottle. They’ll never want to stop.
idioms.comment: Can imply a malevolent force.

references.text: put the genie back in the bottle

idioms.example: It’s been so one-sided that the coach is taking out his best players to level the playing field a bit.
idioms.origin: Alludes to sports played on a field (e.g. soccer), where the advantaged team is occasionally said to be playing downhill or to have the field tilted in their favor.

idioms.example: Andy is so prepared for this exam that he’s just licking his chops.
Andy didn’t do at all well on the exam, so he’s off licking his wounds.
We just sat by the pool, read our books, and napped. It was the life of Reilly.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the 1883 song Is That Mr. Reilly? popularised by the Irish-American singer Pat Rooney. Also possibly alludes to an older Irish Ballad about Willy Riley, who by the end of the ballad is living in comfort with his rich new wife.

idioms.example: Andy’s sounding like a broken record with her constant complaints.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the problem with worn vinyl records that the needle can skip back one groove and thus play the same section of music repeatedly.

idioms.example: Andy’s such a quiet and private guy. Getting him to talk about himself is like pulling teeth.

idioms.keywords: like taking candy from a baby

idioms.example: The workers have drawn their line in the sand. Without some concessions from management, they’re going on strike.
idioms.comment: Implies that crossing the boundary is an irreversible decision that risks serious consequences.
idioms.origin: There are older historical references, but in the US, most probably alludes to the legend from US history that Colonel Travis at the Alamo drew a line in the sand with his sword and asked for volunteers to step over the line and join him in remaining to defend the fort to the last man.

idioms.example: These days, a litmus test for political candidates is whether or not they’re pro-choice.
idioms.comment: Often used in reference to political candidates.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the test for acidity in chemistry, where a strip of litmus paper dipped into a solution turns red if the solution is generally acidic and blue if generally alkaline.

idioms.example: I think they loaded the dice against us. The outcome of this vote was never in doubt.
idioms.origin: Alludes to craps and other dice games, where the dice can be asymmetrically weighted to raise the frequency of certain outcomes.

idioms.example: Andy’s done so much research for this debate. She’s loaded for bear.
Oh, he was loaded to the gills, stumbling around and not making any sense.
They bought the house and all its contents, lock, stock, and barrel.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to early firearms, which consisted primarily of three parts: the lock or firing mechanism, the stock held against the shoulder to support the firearm when firing, and the barrel from which the bullet was projected.

idioms.example: Tact is not Andy’s strong suit. Someone else should deliver the bad news.
idioms.origin: Alludes to some card games where many or high cards in some suit is an advantage.

idioms.keywords: long (or tough) (or hard) row to hoe
idioms.example: Andy is working towards his degree while holding down a full-time job. She’s got a long row to hoe.
The professor’s getting long in the tooth and starting to think about retirement.
They’ve sensed his vulnerability and the long knives are out. He won’t be president much longer.
Andy’s hoping to make the first team, but with his inexperience he’s definitely a long shot.
Andy’s a bright guy, but some of his ideas are just Looney Tunes.
Andy’s a loose cannon, always causing trouble.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the necessity of ensuring that heavy cannon on sailing ships were securely lashed in place to prevent their rolling about and causing major damage.

idioms.example: Andy lost his bearings when he lost his job. He doesn’t know what to do with himself.
idioms.origin: Alludes to navigation, where taking a bearing with a sextant or a map and compass means identifying where one is relative to the target of the bearing.

idioms.example: Andy put everything into her startup, but it failed and she lost her shirt.
Aiming to be as good a pianist as I am is setting yourself a pretty low bar.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to high-jumping in track and field, where a lower bar makes the jump easier.

idioms.keywords: low in (or on) the food chain
idioms.example: I’m too low in the food chain to make those kinds of decisions.
Andy is very low key. She’s always relaxed and calm.

idioms.keywords: low man on the totem pole
idioms.example: As low man on the totem pole, Andy gets stuck with the boring jobs.
Let’s identify the low-hanging fruit and get those jobs out of the way first.
The last test was way too challenging. I think we need to lower the bar.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to high-jumping in track and field, where a low bar makes the jump easier.

idioms.example: Andy’s been playing instead of studying, and her Mom is getting set to lower the boom.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to sailing vessels, where the boom is a large spar which can sometimes swing out of control and thereby cause injury to the unaware.

idioms.example: My new bike is all set up and ready for its maiden voyage.
idioms.origin: Alludes to sailing vessels, where the phrase refers to the first voyage of a ship.

idioms.example: The morale is so low here that these folks are just mailing it in.
You’re in the major leagues now. You have to do your best at all times.
idioms.origin: Alludes to sports at the highest professional level (e.g. Major League Baseball, Major League Soccer).

idioms.example: Everyone else has tried to fix it. There’s no harm in my making a pass at it.
Andy thought her oral exam would be easy, but they made her sweat.
We’ve been waiting all day for the network to be up, so we need to make hay while it still is.
idioms.comment: Often followed by "while the sun shines".
idioms.origin: Alludes to the necessity in farming of harvesting hay while it’s dry.

idioms.example: There was so much pent-up demand for their product that they’re making money hand over fist.
I don’t have enough relevant experience, so I didn’t make the cut for the first round of interviews.
idioms.origin: Alludes to sports teams, where the phrase refers to a player who is not cut from the team's roster but qualifies to be on the team.

idioms.example: You won’t make the grade in medical school without a tremendous amount of work.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to to any of several sources: receiving grades in academic courses, the practice of grading products (e.g. jewels, beef, bonds) for quality, or a railroad train succeeding in climbing a steep grade.

idioms.keywords: march to a different (or (one’s) own) drum (or drummer)
idioms.example: Andy has always marched to a different drum. She’s very creative but a bit eccentric.

references.text: march to the beat of a different drum

idioms.keywords: march to the beat of a different drum
idioms.example: Andy has always marched to a different drum. She’s very creative but a bit eccentric.

references.text: march to a different (or (one’s) own) drum (or drummer)

idioms.example: We have our marching orders, so let’s get to work.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to the use in the military of commands or orders to start infantry marching.

idioms.example: They had a great series of upsets, but they met their Waterloo when they played the previous champs.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical battle at Waterloo in Belgium where the French general Napoleon met his final defeat.

idioms.example: There’s no reason for this quarrel to continue. It’s time to mend fences.
You’ve got 5 minutes to explain and the meter’s already running.
idioms.origin: Alludes to taxis, where the price of journey is determined by a meter that times the journey.

idioms.example: I won’t deal with this group again. It’s a real Mickey Mouse organization.

idioms.origin: Alludes to the Greek myth of Midas, who wished for the ability to turn objects to gold through his touch.

idioms.example: This looks hard, but I’ve done it so many times now that it’s just a milk run.
Why is she here? That’s the million-dollar question, isn’t it?
idioms.origin: Alludes to a 1950s American TV quiz show called The $64,000 Question in which a contestant could win $64,000 with a correct answer to the final question. Over the years, inflation has increased the supposed value of the question.

idioms.example: This is a formal dinner, so please mind your Ps and Qs.
idioms.origin: Of undetermined provenance, but possibly alludes to any of several sources: sailors in the 18th century who were admonished to clean up their peas (pea coats) and queues (braided plaits of hair) when going ashore; early typesetters who were reminded to be careful not to confuse lowercase p’s and q’s; or a 1763 poem by Charles Churchill containing the line "And to instruct him how to use / His As and Bs, and Ps and Qs".

idioms.example: This car is 20 years old, but Andy has kept it in mint condition.
idioms.origin: Alludes to minting coins, where the phrase refers to brand new coins fresh from the mint.

idioms.example: Andy was supposed to be here, but he’s missing in action again.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to the military phrase for someone whose fate after a battle is unknown.

idioms.paraphrase: a gradual, unintended expansion of goals
idioms.example: This project should have taken only 3 months, but mission creep has caused serious delays.
