idioms.origin: Alludes to the military phrase for a mission that grew beyond its original goals.

idioms.example: Unfortunately, most of the Mom-and-Pop stores have not been able to compete with the big retailers.
idioms.comment: Often implies a family-run business.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical existence of many small family-run businesses in the US.

idioms.example: It looks like the executive meeting is over. Here comes the moment of truth.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to the moment in bullfighting when the matador is about to kill the bull.

idioms.paraphrase: a person with the advantage of hindsight
idioms.example: It’s easy to be a Monday morning quarterback, but you can’t really know what you would have done in that situation.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice of second-guessing, on Monday, an American pro football team’s tactics in its game on Sunday.

idioms.example: That requirement definitely throws a monkey wrench into our plan.
idioms.comment: Often used with ‘throw’.

idioms.keywords: more fun than a barrel of monkeys

idioms.example: It looks like we’re going to mothball this project.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice of storing clothes with mothballs to prevent damage from moths.

idioms.example: This is a mother lode of relevant data that we can use to check our own results.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the phrase in mining for an extremely rich vein of ore.

idioms.keywords: move the ball down the field
idioms.example: This is an interesting idea, but does it help us move the ball down the field?
idioms.origin: Alludes to to sports like soccer or football in which a team scores by moving the ball downfield into or over the opponent’s goal.

idioms.example: We’ll never get this project done if the client keeps moving the goalposts.
idioms.origin: Alludes to American football where the goalposts are a target for scoring.

idioms.example: They put in tremendous effort on the research yesterday, but I don’t think they moved the needle much.
idioms.origin: Alludes to any analog instrument that indicates measurement by a needle moving on a numbered background.

idioms.example: Andy’s just muddying the waters with his irrelevant comments.
Mum’s the word. This is supposed to be a surprise party.

idioms.paraphrase: declare absolute determination not to yield
idioms.example: I’ve nailed my colors to the mast on this issue. I’m not giving an inch.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historic practice in naval warfare of nailing the ship’s flag to the mask to show it will not be lowered in surrender.

idioms.example: Do we have the schedule nailed down yet? We’re supposed to get started on the project next week.
The polls show the candidates running neck and neck and the election’s only days away.
idioms.origin: Alludes to horse racing, where two horses running side by side are said to be neck and neck.

idioms.example: We don’t often see people from the big city in this neck of the woods.
We have a decent nest egg, but we’d be more comfortable with a bit more.
idioms.origin: Alludes to an egg put in a hen’s next to encourage it to lay more.

idioms.keywords: never got out of the gate
idioms.example: Without any backing, their start-up never got out of the gate.
idioms.origin: Alludes to originally to horse racing, where the horses begin the race behind a gate that releases them at the start.

idioms.example: Andy lost that debate. He never laid a glove on his opponent.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to boxing, where the competitors wear gloves.

idioms.example: Without any backing, their start-up never left the starting line.
idioms.origin: Alludes to any form of racing where the beginning is marked by a line.

idioms.keywords: new kid on the block (or in town)
idioms.paraphrase: the new person in the group
idioms.example: Andy was always the new kid on the block, so he had to learn how to make friends quickly.
idioms.comment: Implies that the new person is unaware of local customs.

idioms.example: There’s a new sheriff in town, so you kids will have to be on your best behavior.
We have to nip this idea in the bud or the kids will never give up on it.
This game has been nip and tuck the whole way.
This is a really solid essay. The teaching assistant is just nit picking.

idioms.keywords: no dog in this (or the) fight
idioms.example: Let’s stay out of this argument. We’ve got no dog in this fight.

idioms.paraphrase: no harm was done, no penalty is required
idioms.example: I know I rolled that stop sign, officer, but can’t we just call this no harm, no foul?
idioms.origin: Alludes to the phrase used in informal games of basketball and other sports to indicate that a foul with no effect on a play is not called.

idioms.example: They went at it with no holds barred and both said things they regret.
idioms.origin: Alludes to wrestling, where the phrase means there are no limitations on what holds can be used.
Alludes to trench warfare, where the phrase refers to the area between opposing trenches.

idioms.paraphrase: I’m done acting reasonably and politely
no space at the intended destination
idioms.example: We wanted to join them for dinner, but there was no room at the inn.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the Christian legend that Mary and Joseph were turned away from a full inn and had to spend the night in a stable.

idioms.example: Andy’s no spring chicken, but she still skis extremely well.
The boss is in a terrible mood today, and his office is a no-fly zone.
idioms.origin: Alludes to aviation, where restrictions can be placed on entry into some areas of airspace. During warfare, no-fly zones are enforced militarily.

idioms.example: Andy is nose to the grindstone this week with final exams coming up.
This is not my first rodeo. You can skip teaching me the basics.
Don’t expect much of me today. I haven’t been sleeping well and I’m not firing on all cylinders.
idioms.origin: Alludes to a poorly tuned engine.

idioms.example: Andy’s science project is coming along nicely, but it’s not ready for prime time.
idioms.origin: Alludes to a TV show being of sufficient quality to be shown during prime viewing hours.

idioms.example: That was a decent play but nothing to write home about.
I’ve got nothing up my sleeve. What you see here is all I’ve got to work with.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the possibility of cheating at cards by hiding cards up one’s sleeve.

idioms.example: Andy’s a bit of an odd duck. He always approaches problems a bit differently.
We’ve moved all the important stuff. There are just odds and ends left.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to the historical phrase "odd ends", referring to pieces of cloth or lumber leftover after manufacture.

idioms.example: I think that estimate is significantly off base.
idioms.origin: Alludes to baseball, where a player off base is at risk of being put out.

idioms.example: His treatment of Andy was way off base. She didn’t deserve that.
idioms.origin: Alludes to baseball, where a player off base is at risk of being put out.

idioms.example: Off hand, I’d say there were 500 people there.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to shooting, where the phrase refers to shooting with the non-dominant hand.

idioms.example: I’m sorry that we’ve gotten off on the wrong foot. I apologize for my presumptuousness.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to a soldier or member of a marching band starting to march on the incorrect foot.

idioms.example: Andy was full of good ideas right off the bat.
idioms.origin: baseball?

idioms.example: His remarks were off the cuff but still very eloquent.
You’re off the hook this time. Everyone gets a second chance.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to fishing, where from the fish's point of view being on the hook is unfortunate.

idioms.example: One of the board members went off the reservation and disclosed our internal deliberations to the press.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice in US history of confining Native Americans to reservations from which they were forbidden to leave on penalty of being considered renegades.

idioms.example: Andy was doing so well, but she’s fallen off the wagon lately.
idioms.comment: Implies drinking again after having been sober for a time.
idioms.origin: A shortened version of an earlier phrase "on the water-wagon" that implied a person was drinking water rather than alcohol.

idioms.example: Andy throws out ideas that are completely off the wall but sometimes brilliant.
Andy’s suddenly enthusiastic about this plan, so I think we’re off to the races.
Professor Andy is one of the old guard, but he’s still open to new ideas.
idioms.comment: Implies personnel accustomed to traditional ways and resistant to change.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the changing of a military guard, where the current guards are replaced by fresh ones.

idioms.example: I’m old school about these things. I think children need firm and clear rules.
Let Andy show us around. These are her old stomping grounds.
idioms.origin: Alludes to areas frequented by herds of animals.

idioms.example: The notion that spilling salt is bad luck is just an old wives’ tale.
idioms.comment: Often implies an allegedly unfounded belief.

idioms.example: This old bike is on its last legs. I can no longer find parts to repair it.
Andy feels very offended and is really on her high horse.
They took me completely by surprise. That possibility wasn’t even on my radar.
We need to be on our toes and attentive today. These folks always have a hidden agenda.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to ballet, where dancers are often on tiptoe, or sports, where it is usually advantageous to be on one’s toes as opposed to flatfooted.

idioms.example: Andy’s really on a roll lately. She hasn’t lost a match in weeks.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to craps, where the phrase indicates a series of positive rolls of the dice.

idioms.example: I’ve got very little money for this trip, so I’m traveling on a shoestring.

idioms.keywords: on a wing and a prayer
idioms.example: Andy was completely unprepared, so she just auditioned on a wing and a prayer.
Andy coaches a fractious group of kids, but he manages to keep things on an even keel.
idioms.origin: Alludes to a keeled boat being in a stable, balanced position.

idioms.example: Andy’s on auto pilot, just putting in his time until he leaves this job.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the mechanism on planes that enables them to fly for periods of time without intervention by a pilot.

idioms.example: He’s on cloud nine since Andy asked him to the prom.
I’ve been on pins and needles waiting for the exam results.
Andy’s on point today. She’s presenting our proposal to the committee.

idioms.origin: from Skid Road in Seattle
Alludes to the dispensing of beer in bars or from kegs using a tap.

idioms.example: I’ve had this work on the back burner for weeks, but I think I finally have time for it.
Now that the departmental budget is decided, we’ll find out which projects are on the chopping block.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the solid, thick block of wood in butcher’s shops on which meat is chopped into various cuts.

idioms.example: I’m still on the fence. I’m just not sure I’m up to that amount of effort.
The press will have lots of tough questions. Who’s volunteering to be on the firing line?
idioms.origin: Alludes to the front line of soldiers in a battle who do most of the firing.

idioms.example: Andy landed an easy job and now she’s on the gravy train.
I paid for dinner last week. I think you’re on the hook this time.

idioms.origin: Probably alludes to railroads, where a train on the right track is headed for the correct destination.

idioms.example: Andy worked hard but I think her little startup business is on the ropes.
idioms.origin: Alludes to boxing, where the phrase indicates that a boxer is losing the bout.

idioms.example: We had a strategy meeting yesterday and I think we’re all on the same page now.
Andy and I are usually on the same wavelength, but apparently not today.
I’m not on this project, so I’m just on the sidelines for this discussion.
idioms.origin: Alludes to court or field sports, where inactive players are on the sidelines.

idioms.example: Andy’s back on the wagon this week, but who knows about next week?
I would avoid Andy today. She’s on the warpath about the failure of her pet project.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to the historic use of the phrase by Native Americans to identify individuals headed for battle.

idioms.example: You’re already on thin ice. You need to do all the remaining assignments to get a decent grade.
He’s a one-trick pony, but he’s very good at what he does.
idioms.origin: Alludes to vaudeville, where some acts featured horses or ponies that performed tricks.

idioms.example: I’d really like to help you with your speech, but unfortunately I have other fish to fry.
After the failure of her pet project, Andy’s out for blood today.
That sort of behavior in the classroom is out of bounds.
That idea sure came out of left field.
He’s completely out of step with us on political issues.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to a soldier or member of a marching band not marching in unison.

idioms.example: He had some really interesting thoughts about the show right out of the chute.
idioms.origin: rodeo

idioms.example: He had some really interesting thoughts about the show right out of the starting blocks.
idioms.origin: Alludes to track, where sprinters position their feet on blocks for the start.

idioms.example: Andy appears to be out to lunch today. I wonder what’s on her mind.
They have us over a barrel. We have no option but to take their offer.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the historical method of rolling a drowning victim over a barrel to attempt resuscitation.

idioms.example: The light show at that concert was completely over the top.
That witness didn’t help us at all. Calling him to testify might have been an own goal.
idioms.origin: Alludes to sports like hockey or soccer where a player can accidentally send the puck or ball into his or her own goal and score a point for the opposing team.

idioms.example: We just found out we both passed the bar, so we’re out to paint the town red!
I thought I found a source for antique woodworking tools, but it didn’t pan out.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to panning for gold, where the phrase refers to a claim that yielded results.

idioms.example: He’s won his last few matches, but I think he’s really a paper tiger.
Andy didn’t arrive on time, but that’s par for the course.
idioms.origin: Alludes to golf, where par is the standard score.

idioms.example: I hoped we’d get an honest answer from her, but she’s adhering to the party line.
idioms.comment: Implies an explanation dictated by higher authority.
idioms.origin: Alludes to a political party dictating specific policies to its members.

idioms.example: I hate to be a party pooper, but we’ve got to get home.
He’s reluctant to retire, but he knows it’s time to pass the baton.
idioms.comment: Implies transfer of responsibility to a new generation.
idioms.origin: Alludes to a relay in track, where one runner passes a baton to the next.

idioms.example: Does our new employee pass muster?
idioms.origin: Alludes to the military practice of calling soldiers together for inspection.

idioms.example: Andy hates making hard decisions and he always tries to pass the buck.
idioms.comment: Implies that the responsibility should have been accepted.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to the game of poker, where historically the dealer was changed by passing a buck knife from one player to the next.

idioms.example: Your explanation doesn’t pass the smell test. It’s too contrived.
He’s reluctant to retire, but he knows it’s time to pass the torch.
idioms.comment: Implies transfer of responsibility to a new generation.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the tradition of passing a torch by relay from one host city of the Olympic Games to the next, itself a practice derived from the ancient Greeks use of a torch as a baton in a relay race.

idioms.example: He’s past his sell-by date but he just refuses to retire.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to the practice of stamping a date on a food product to indicate the end of its useful life.

idioms.example: Andy’s paying her back in spades for her disgraceful insults.
idioms.comment: Usually implies a response to a negative action.

idioms.example: We’ve been procrastinating all term and now it’s time to pay the piper.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the legend of the Pied Piper of Hamelin in which the Piper leads the town’s rats away from Hamelin with his magic pipe, and subsequently leads the town’s children away also when the town refuses to pay him.

idioms.example: There’s no other source for components of such quality, so unfortunately we’ll have to pay through the nose for them.
We can do without the snide comments from the peanut gallery.
idioms.comment: Usually implies rowdy onlookers. Used informally.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to the cheapest seats in a vaudeville theater, from where patrons heckled and threw peanuts at poor performers.

idioms.example: Any group of kids usually establishes a pecking order within a few days.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to the order of dominance established in a flock of chickens by pecking.

idioms.example: We’re first in line for tickets, so we get the pick of the litter.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice of granting or selling someone the first choice of a litter of dogs, cats, etc.

idioms.example: Andy thinks his app will make him rich, but it’s just pie in the sky.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the expectation of a reward in the afterlife as opposed to one here and now.

idioms.example: Now you’re just piling on. I think Andy has been teased enough.
idioms.comment: Often used in the progressive tense, as "piling on".
idioms.origin: Alludes to to the now illegal practice in American football of jumping on a player who is already down.

idioms.example: There’s nothing wrong with the computer. I believe we have a case of pilot error here.
idioms.origin: Alludes to flying aircraft, where the pilot has primary responsibility.

idioms.example: It’s ten o’clock, kids. Time to pipe down.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the naval practice of using a whistle or pipe to signal the end of a shift.

idioms.example: Andy thinks his app will make him rich, but it’s just a pipe dream.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the dreams or visions produced by smoking a pipe of opium.

idioms.example: We’ve been riding for an hour. Does anyone besides me need a pit stop?
idioms.comment: Often implies a break for natural relief.
idioms.origin: Alludes to auto racing, where a race car must occasionally stop in the pit inside the track to get gas, replace tires, etc.

idioms.keywords: play (one’s) cards close to (one’s) chest (or vest)
idioms.example: I don’t know what Andy’s term paper is about. He’s playing his cards close to his chest.
idioms.origin: Alludes to card games where one hold’s one cards close to prevent one’s opponents from seeing your hand.

idioms.example: If you play your cards right, the professor will sometimes give you an extension on your assignment.
idioms.origin: Obviously alludes to playing well in a card game.

idioms.example: These folks play hardball, so we’ll have to be firm in negotiating this contract.

idioms.paraphrase: deal with things as they arise
idioms.example: We’re not sure what we’re going to do in New Orleans. We’re going to play it by ear.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the ability of some people to hear a piece of music and play it back without recourse to the score.

idioms.example: This is my third reassignment this month. I feel like I’m playing musical chairs.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to the game of musical chairs, where players walk around a group of chairs (one less than the number of players) while music plays and then seek to avoid elimination by grabbing a chair when the music stops.
Alludes to the opossum (or possum), which can feign death when threatened.

idioms.example: Andy has improved so much that she’s no longer playing second fiddle to her peers.
idioms.comment: Usually implies that the person in the secondary role is dissatisfied and feels he or she could do better.
idioms.origin: Alludes to orchestras, where the best violin (or any instrument) player is formally termed first chair and the next best is termed second chair.

idioms.paraphrase: take the opposite side of an argument
idioms.example: I’ll play the devil’s advocate here. I can suggest a few reasons why we might not hire him.
idioms.comment: Implies taking the opposite side not necessarily out of belief but for the sake of ensuring full debate.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice in the Catholic Church of designating a person to argue against someone’s sainthood or canonization.

idioms.comment: Usually implies romantic opportunities.
idioms.origin: Alludes to horse racing in Britain, where the phrase signified betting on every horse in a field but the favorite.

idioms.paraphrase: deal with one crisis after another

idioms.example: I never expected to get past the first round, much less the third. I’m playing with house money now.
idioms.origin: Alludes to gambling, where the phrase signifies to win enough to no longer be risking one’s own money.

idioms.example: Andy did really well in her interview. I’m pleased as punch for her.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the character Punch from the historic comedy puppet show Punch and Judy.

idioms.example: Andy’s the point man today. He’s presenting our proposal to the committee.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the military, where the phrase refers to the leading person in a military movement.

idioms.example: I doubt that the committee can judge us fairly now that those rumors have poisoned the well.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice of raiders poisoning the well or a target town or castle to make it unusable.

idioms.example: Andy has such a poker face. That’s what makes him a good practical joker.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice in card games of not expressing any emotion that could indicate the quality of one’s hand.

idioms.example: There are lots of applicants for the new manager position, but I think Andy’s qualifications give her the pole position.
idioms.origin: Alludes to horse or auto racing, where the phrase refers to the advantageous inside position at the beginning of a race.

idioms.example: We agreed to share the bill, so now it’s time to pony up.

idioms.comment: Implies dealings that are not entirely legitimate.
idioms.origin: from literal barrel of pork to metaphorical livelihood

idioms.example: Andy is the poster child of procrastination.
idioms.origin: March of Dimes

idioms.example: Andy keeps trying different crazy schemes, always looking for his pot of gold.
idioms.comment: Often followed by "at the end of the rainbow".
idioms.origin: Alludes to the longstanding myth that a pot of gold awaits anyone who reaches the end of a rainbow.

idioms.example: Their company appears to have developed a wonderful new technology, but it’s all just a Potemkin Village.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the possibly apocryphal story of fake villages constructed to impress Empress Catherine of Russia by her lover Grigory Potemkin.

idioms.example: Big banks never yield on late payments. They always get their pound of flesh.
idioms.comment: Implies a very rigid adherence to an obligation by the holder of the obligation.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the specification of a pound of flesh as collateral for a loan in Shakespeare’s play The Merchant of Venice.

idioms.example: I’ve already decided I’m voting for your candidate. You’re preaching to the choir here.
If Andy wants to be truly popular, she needs to get out and press the flesh with her fans.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice of polticians mingling and shaking hands in crowds while campaigning.

idioms.example: They have a good plan and now they just need a small investment to prime the pump.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the necessity of adding water to some water pumps to force air out and ready the pump for use.

idioms.example: Andy’s walking down the primrose path straight into disaster.
idioms.origin: From Shakespeare’s use of the phrase in the play Hamlet .

idioms.example: Everyone thinks that getting a law degree will lead them to the promised land, but it’s not that simple.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the Biblical story of the Israelites leaving Egypt in search of the land promised them by God.

idioms.paraphrase: only the actual results reveal success or failure
idioms.example: We can’t know it’s a valid experiment until we run it. The proof is in the pudding.
Andy knows she’s already won the debate, so she’s starting to pull her punches a bit.
idioms.origin: Alludes to boxing, where a boxer may ease up on their opponent once victory is certain.

idioms.keywords: pull a (or the) rabbit out of a (or the) hat
idioms.example: Andy pulled a rabbit out of a hat this time, but she won’t always be so lucky.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the magician’s trick of pulling a rabbit or other unexpected object out of an apparently empty hat.

idioms.example: If you want to win this race, you need to pull out all the stops.
idioms.origin: Alludes to playing a pipe organ, where the phrase refers to the stops which allow air into pipes when pulled out, thereby increasing volume.

idioms.example: It’s time to pull the plug on this project. We can see now that it isn’t going to work.
idioms.origin: electricity?

idioms.example: We’ve found no new voters to register here. It’s time to pull up stakes.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the early mining practice of placing stakes around an area to mark it as claimed or pulling up tent stakes when taking down a tent. [two origina]

idioms.example: Of course that’s not true. I was just pulling your leg.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the supposed historical practice of tripping someone before robbing them or possibly the historical practice of pulling on the legs of someone being hanged to speed their death. [two origina]

idioms.example: They’re a team from a small school, but they always seem to punch above their weight.
idioms.origin: Alludes to boxing, where an individual may be stronger than expected for their weight class.

idioms.example: There are a bunch of smart people at that lab and they’re always pushing the envelope.
idioms.origin: Alludes to aviation, where the idiom refers to stressing an aircraft beyond its technical specifications.

idioms.example: Don’t push the panic button just yet! We’ve got one more fix we can try.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the common presence on a machine of a button, usually red, to immediately halt the machine in case of emergence.

idioms.example: Andy couldn’t find a job, so he’s putting out his shingle.
idioms.comment: Usually implies a professional such as lawyer or architect opening an office.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice of identifying one’s business using a shingle as a sign.

idioms.example: The coach is putting his foot down. He’s tired of the team’s lackadaisical attitude.
I put my foot in my mouth this time. I let it slip about the surprise party.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the phrase foot-in-mouth being a play on the hoof-and-mouth disease that afflicts cattle.

idioms.example: The department wants to put him out to pasture, but he’s very resistant.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice in horse racing of retiring a racehorse after its racing career to become a stud or broodmare.

idioms.example: You had better be prepared for your interview. She will put you through your paces.
idioms.origin: dressage?

idioms.example: It looks like we’re putting this project in mothballs.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice of storing clothes with mothballs to prevent damage from moths.

idioms.example: They’ve put their science project on ice. They’re done and satisfied with it.
I’m sorry to put a damper on the festivities, but it’s time to get back to work.
idioms.comment: Implies that the reduction is not welcomed.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the damper used in fireplaces and fuel-burning stoves to reduce the amount of air feeding the fire.

idioms.keywords: put a stake in the ground
idioms.example: The president has to put a stake in the ground on this issue. She can’t back down any further.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the Native American practice of typing oneself to a stake in battle to indicate no intention of retreat or the historical practice in mining of placing stakes around an area to mark a claim. [two origins]

idioms.example: I don’t put much stock in what she says. It’s mostly just rumors.
idioms.comment: Often used negatively, as shown.
idioms.origin: stock market?

idioms.keywords: put the genie back in the bottle
idioms.example: Once the secret is out, there’s no way to put the genie back in the bottle.

references.text: let the genie out of the bottle

idioms.origin: Alludes to the myth of Aladdin, which includes a magic lamp that when rubbed produces a genie of magical powers.

idioms.keywords: put the pedal to the metal
idioms.example: Our science project is due tomorrow. It’s time to put the pedal to the metal.
idioms.origin: automobiles

idioms.example: If the screening committee thinks you’re not completely honest with them, they will really put the screws to you.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the medieval use of screws to torture individuals by exerting immense pressure on their toes or fingers.

idioms.example: Andy has been put through the wringer this term. He’s simply exhausted.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to the wringer previously attached to washing machines to squeeze the water out of wet clothes.

idioms.example: We’ve heard how good you are at this, but now it’s time to put up or shut up.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to gambling, where the phrase directed a player to either ante up or withdraw.

idioms.example: Grab your rain gear. It’s raining cats and dogs out there.
idioms.origin: animals slipping off straw roofs in the rain [??]

idioms.example: I hate to rain on your parade, but we still don’t know who won the election.
Andy needs to raise her game if she wants to succeed in law school.
They’re not happy with the jury’s decision and they’re raising Cain in front of the courthouse.
It’s really unfair to raise the bar after the students have already prepared for the exam.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the track event of high jumping, where competitors must jump over ever higher bars.

idioms.example: The football team won its first game this year and the students are absolutely raising the roof.
She raised the roof when she found out what they had done.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice in medieval churches of hauling a heretic over hot coals.

idioms.example: Andy made a serious miscalculation and his manager is raking him over the coals.
Andy’s a rare bird. You will not find a nicer, more generous person.

idioms.origin: From "rearing to go"?

idioms.example: After that debate performance, his supporters are disappearing like rats from a sinking ship.
You’re certainly feisty this morning. Who rattled your cage?
idioms.comment: Usually used humorously.

idioms.example: Andy really hadn’t done anything wrong, but the supervisor read her the riot act anyway.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the Riot Act in historic Great Britain, which authorized local officials to declare an assembly of people illegal after first reading them the Act.

idioms.example: I can read between the lines. Whatever her stated reasons, she really just doesn’t want to come.
When I read the tea leaves, I don’t see this working out very well.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice in some cultures of interpreting the future based on the tea leaves remaining after drinking.

idioms.example: Her campaign speech is improving, but it’s not quite ready for prime time.
idioms.comment: Often used negatively, as shown.
idioms.origin: Alludes to television, where the phrase refers to prime viewing time during which only the best shows are aired.

idioms.example: Until we deal with the fundamental problem, we’re just rearranging the deck chairs.
idioms.comment: Implies diversion of attention from an actual crisis. Often followed by "on the Titanic".
idioms.origin: Alludes to the sinking of the Titanic or other ship, during which rearranging deck chairs is obviously futile.

idioms.example: He’s an important client so they’re rolling out the red carpet for him.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice of greeting dignitaries by rolling out a carpet on which they enter.

idioms.example: There are so many red flags in this proposal, it’s difficult to identify the worst.
The wobbly wheel was a red herring. The brakes were the real problem.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice of dragging a smoked herring across a trail to distract hunting dogs from the trail or of dragging a herring along a trail to train hunting dogs to follow the trail.

idioms.example: We’re awash in red ink this quarter.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the accounting practice of using red ink for negative amounts.
from railroad men visiting brothels and hanging their lanterns outside

idioms.example: There’s a huge amount of red tape involved in starting your own business.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice, initially in Spain, of wrapping important documents in red ribbon or tape.

idioms.example: It’s a red-letter day! I finally got one of my articles published.
idioms.comment: Implies a day that marks a significant achievement.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical use of red to indicate important days in the calendar, initially in the Roman Republic.

idioms.example: This problem has already been solved. We don’t need to reinvent the wheel here.
Andy has apparently reversed field. He no longer wants to go to law school.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the action of an athlete, particularly in field sports like American football, of drastically changing direction to evade opponents.

idioms.example: I can’t go out this Saturday. I have to ride herd on a bunch of first graders.
Andy’s in charge here. I’m just riding shotgun.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice of a man with a shotgun riding alongside a stagecoach driver to provide protection.

idioms.example: She doesn’t really care for Andy, but he thinks she does. He’s definitely riding for a fall.
He was really enthusiastic about this project right out of the gate.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to horse racing, where the horses begin behind a gate that releases, freeing them to start the race.

idioms.example: I’ll take this on. This kind of challenge is right up my alley.
Here’s a picture of her from that trip. Does this ring a bell?
My approach is to read the chapter,  study the vocabulary, do the exercises, then rinse and repeat.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the instructions, commonly used on shampoo, to wash and rinse, then wash and rinse again.

idioms.example: Without consumer protections, large corporations would just rob us blind.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the act of stealing from a blind beggar’s cup of donated money.

idioms.paraphrase: couple with a much younger person
idioms.example: My wife looks so much younger that I’m accused of robbing the cradle.
I’m sorry to rock the boat, but I think we’ve overlooked something important.
All the top competitors have signed up. This event has attracted quite a rogues gallery.
idioms.comment: Often used facetiously.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the array of photos of wanted criminals sometimes posted in law enforcement offices, possibly first used by the Pinkerton Agency in the mid-1800s.

idioms.example: They were hoping for a quick roll in the hay, but they couldn’t find any privacy.
idioms.comment: Used informally.

idioms.example: This sort of bureaucratic obstacle is not uncommon, so you have to learn to roll with the punches.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to boxing, where the phrase means to move so as to turn a direct punch into a glancing blow.

idioms.example: We provide the parts and tools, but when it comes to assembly it’s strictly roll your own.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice of making one’s own tobacco or marijuana cigarette with loose leaves and rolling paper.

idioms.keywords: Rome wasn’t built in a day
idioms.example: Yes, this is a very big project, but Rome wasn’t built in a day.
They’re a good group of kids except for one rotten apple who makes them all look bad.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the old saying that "one rotten apple spoils the barrel", attributed originally to Benjamin Franklin.

idioms.paraphrase: taking successive turns so as to include everyone in a group
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice, originating in the navy, of putting signatures to a document in a circle so that no first signer, and therefore no ringleader, can be identified.

idioms.paraphrase: a tournament in which every competitor plays every other competitor
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice, originating in the navy, of putting signatures to a document in a circle so that no first signer, and therefore no ringleader, can be identified.

idioms.example: The board of directors doesn’t do anything but rubber-stamp the executives’ decisions.
I gather that she ruffled your feathers a bit with that comment.
As a rule of thumb, you should boil water for one minute to purify it.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice of using one’s thumb to estimate a measurement.
chickens

idioms.example: I’m new here, and I don’t want to start by violating any rules of the road.

idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice of selling unclaimed cargo (or rummage) from a ship.

idioms.example: We’ve been looking at the data all week and I think we’ve finally run the anomaly to ground.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice in hunting of chasing prey until it tires and finds a place to hide.

idioms.example: I think it’s a good idea, but let’s run it up the flagpole and see what the others say.
His manager is running interference while he works on the project.
idioms.origin: Alludes to American football, where the phrase indicates a player protecting the runner by blocking would-be tacklers.

idioms.example: Those cars look good, but functionally they’re just run of the mill.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the normal quality of product produced by a grain mill.

idioms.example: You’ve worked too hard this week. I think you’re running on empty and really need a break.
I’ve been working on this all day and I’m running out of steam.
His already has another job lined up, so he’s just running out the clock here.
idioms.origin: Alludes to timed games in sports, where the leading competitor or team may try to slow play and exhaust the remaining time in order to win the game.

idioms.keywords: run over by a Mack truck

idioms.example: The students’ answers run the gamut from completely ridiculous to very insightful.
She’s dealt with every question so far. I think she might run the table.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the game of pool, where the phrase refers to pocketing all one’s remaining balls to win the game.

idioms.example: I believe he’s just saber rattling. I don’t think he really intends to punish anyone for that prank.
This tradition is a sacred cow around here. Criticize it at your own risk.
idioms.comment: Implies reverence for no currently discernible reason.
idioms.origin: Alludes to Hinduism, where cows are venerated, they cannot be harmed, and eating beef is prohibited

idioms.example: Even though we’re all at fault, it looks like Andy is our sacrificial lamb.
idioms.comment: Implies that the designated person is not guilty of any transgression.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the ancient Abrahamic religious tradition of sacrificing a lamb, a very valuable possession, to curry the favor of God.

idioms.example: Oh, those were my salad days, after college when I had a good job, plenty of money, and no responsibilities.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the Shakespearean phrase in Antony and Cleopatra originally used to indicate a period of youthful inexperience.

idioms.example: Andy comes from a long line of farmers. They’re real salt-of-the-earth folks.
idioms.comment: Often implies rural as well as good, honest, and unpretentious.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the phrase used by Jesus in the Sermon on the Mount.

idioms.example: Andy was saved by the bell when her boss had to take a phone call.
idioms.origin: Alludes to boxing, where a competitor in dire straits may be saved by the bell indicating the end of the round.

idioms.example: I’ve tried unsuccessfully all day to solve this puzzle. I guess it’s time to say uncle.
idioms.origin: most recently, from kids fighting

idioms.keywords: scraping the bottom of the barrel
idioms.paraphrase: relying on the last and least desirable resources
idioms.example: This is all the paper we could find. We’re really scraping the bottom of the barrel.
idioms.origin: nautical

idioms.example: There’s been a sea change in the school’s policies. They now think school uniforms are a good idea.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to to the use of the phrase by the Roman orator Cicero comparing the lowest in society to the sediment of wine in a near empty barrel.

idioms.example: I’m definitely second string in this crew. Most of them have much more experience than I do.
idioms.origin: Possibly originally alludes to a line of pack horses or mules connected one to the next by ropes; now commonly used to refer to reserve players on sports teams.

idioms.example: I don’t know what her secret sauce is, but all the boys think she’s special.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to to the sauce used on MacDonald’s Big Macs, the ingredients of which are a trade secret.

idioms.example: You are always selling yourself short. You’re better at this than you think.
idioms.origin: stock market?

idioms.example: Andy set the bar too high this time. None of his students passed the quiz.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to high-jumping in track and field, where a higher bar makes the jump harder.

idioms.example: Andy set the bar too low this time. Every one of his students aced the quiz.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to high-jumping in track and field, where a lower bar makes the jump easier.

idioms.example: I’ve used these skis for 4 seasons and they have definitely exceeded their shelf life.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the length of time perishable products remain available for sale (on the shelf).

idioms.example: Andy keeps telling us different stories. He seems to be running a shell game.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the ancient gambling game where a person shuffles a pea around under 3 shells while another person attempts to follow the action and identify where the ball ends up.

idioms.paraphrase: suffering from a barrage of unfortunate events
idioms.example: I’m a bit shell shocked. The exams were much more difficult than I expected.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the phenomenon of soldiers being psychologically battered by being under sustained artillery fire.

idioms.example: When she found out Andy was dating someone else, it was a real shit storm.
I shot my wad on those first few hills. I have no energy left for any more.
idioms.origin: Alludes to forgetting in the heat of battle to insert a bullet into a muzzle-loading rifle and so shooting only the wad that goes in before the bullet.

idioms.example: Andy shot herself in the foot with her last argument.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice of avoiding military service by "accidentally" injuring oneself, commonly by shooting oneself in the foot; or possibly alludes to a cowboy in the old west accidentally shooting himself in the foot by drawing his pistol too quickly from his holster.

idioms.example: We’re just shooting the shit. There’s nothing important going on here.
I tried to present my case to the professor,  but she gave me short shrift.
idioms.origin: Alludes to shrift, the Catholic practice where a priest hears a confession and absolves the confessor, a ritual that historically could be shortened for condemned criminals.

idioms.example: This letter is only a shot across our bow, but we should take it seriously.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the naval practice of one ship shooting across another’s bow as a warning before more serious action is taken.

idioms.example: The initial positive feedback was a real shot in the arm for me.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the medical practice of giving shots of medicines or vaccines in the upper arm.

idioms.example: Shove off, buddy. You have no business in this conversation.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the naval use of the phrase to indicate a ship leaving the pier.

idioms.example: The car’s all packed. Let’s shove off.
Andy’s been showing false colors, just pretending to be in favor of our plan.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice of warships or pirate ships flying a false flag to misidentify themselves.

idioms.example: Andy’s no shrinking violet, so you’ll find out what he thinks of this idea.
There’s no silver bullet. We just need to investigate all the options.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the 1950s TV show The Lone Ranger where the hero always left a silver bullet behind after his exploits as his calling card.

idioms.example: The kids are all singing the same tune. They don’t know how the fender got a dent in it.
idioms.comment: Can imply a false or prearranged story.

idioms.example: You two go ahead to the opening. I’m going to sit this one out.
idioms.origin: Alludes to dancing, where the phrase refers to a person not participating.

idioms.example: Andy is a sitting duck out there, but no one’s stepping forward to support her.
idioms.origin: Alludes to hunting, where a duck on the ground or in the water is easy to shoot.

idioms.example: You’re already skating on thin ice. You need to do all the remaining assignments to get a decent grade.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the danger posed by venturing onto a lake that is not completely frozen.

idioms.example: I don’t know what the skeletons in the closet are, but they’re awfully tight-lipped about their history.
idioms.origin: Alludes to probably apocryphal story of a murderer hiding their victim in a closet.

idioms.example: I don’t care whose idea we adopt. I have no skin in the game.
This is certainly a setback, but I don’t think the sky is falling quite yet.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the folk tale of Chicken Little, who believes the sky is falling  and sets out to alert the world after an acorn falls on its head.

idioms.example: That test should have been a slam dunk for me, but there were some very tricky questions on it.
idioms.origin: Alludes to basketball, where the phrase means a certain two points when a player forcefully throws the ball down into the basket.

idioms.example: They seriously violated some safety regulations but all they got was a slap on the wrist.

idioms.origin: Alludes to the possibly apocryphal myth of gangsters disposing of bodies by submerging them in rivers or the ocean.

idioms.example: You can try to get a straight answer from him, but he’s slippery as a greased pig.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the contest sometimes staged a county fairs where contestants try to catch a pig coated with vegetable or mineral oil.

idioms.example: Andy was slow out of the gate, so now she has to rush her work.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to horse racing, where the horses begin behind a gate that releases, freeing them to start the race.

idioms.example: I’ve been regularly putting a little bit of my salary into a slush fund for just such little luxuries.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the nautical practice in which a ship’s cook sold the extra fat or grease (the "slush") generated from cooking for a little extra cash for supplies for the galley.
fishing

idioms.example: The reporters smell blood now. They will not let this story go without some answers.
idioms.comment: Sometimes followed by "in the water".
idioms.origin: Alludes to the capacity of sharks and other scavengers to smell blood at a distance and come to partake of the carcass.

idioms.example: Their software is all smoke and mirrors.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice of magicians to use smoke, mirrors, and other distractions to mask their trickery.

idioms.example: I’m surprised that our latest version didn’t pass the smoke test.
idioms.origin: Alludes to a basic test in plumbing to inject smoke into a system of pipes to determine if it leaks.

idioms.example: We all know that Andy is cheating somehow, but so far we have no smoking gun.
Andy’s a real snake oil salesman. You can’t take him at his word.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historic practice of selling the oil of the Chinese Water Snake to treat joint pain, a practice that in the historic American West became highly fraudulent over time.

idioms.example: There’s so much angst about who’s going with whom to the prom. We have a real soap opera going on.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the ubiquitous American daytime TV shows in which the focus is on interpersonal drama.

idioms.paraphrase: light touch [without real substance]; avoidance of substance

idioms.example: They appear to be doing well, but something is rotten in Denmark.
idioms.origin: Alludes to a quote in the Shakespearen play Hamlet.

idioms.example: Andy has something up her sleeve. She’s being very coy about her plans.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the possibility of cheating at cards by hiding cards up one’s sleeve.
begat in the galley, born under a gun

idioms.example: Unlike our competitors, we offer a soup-to-nuts solution.

idioms.paraphrase: attribution of undesirability to something unobtainable
idioms.example: Andy claims she doesn’t really want to go to the dance, but I think that’s just sour grapes because she wasn’t invited.
idioms.origin: Alludes to Aesop’s fable about the fox who, when he couldn’t jump high enough to reach some grapes, decided that they were probably sour anyway.

idioms.example: Speak of the devil, Andy just arrived.
idioms.comment: Only used when having just mentioned the person in question.

idioms.example: Andy doesn’t ever do anything on his own initiative. He’s just a spear carrier for the board.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to the front-line, low-ranking soldiers in ancient armies who were armed primarily with spears.

idioms.example: You didn’t spill the beans, did you? This is supposed to be a surprise party!
I think we’re just spinning our wheels here. We need a new approach.
idioms.origin: Obviously alludes to the tendency of wheels to spin when a vehicle is trying to gain traction in snow or mud.
military

idioms.example: Sorry, I have no pixie dust to sprinkle on your dilemma.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the magical powers attributed to the glittering dust particles emanating from the magic wand of fairies, particularly the Disney character Tinkerbell.

idioms.example: Between the demands of his job and the needs of his family, Andy’s caught in a real squeeze play.
idioms.origin: Though other uses are known, probably alludes to the play in baseball where the batter hits a sacrifice bunt to allow the runner on third base to score.

idioms.example: Andy really wants the job, but he’s facing a stacked deck.
idioms.origin: Alludes to poker and other card games, where advantage can be gained by prearranging the deck.

idioms.example: I’m staking a claim to at least one piece of that cake.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice in mining of placing stakes around an area to mark a claim.

idioms.example: This scheme is really just a stalking horse. I’m trying to gauge people’s reactions.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice of a hunter hiding behind a horse to get closer to quarry, particularly wildfowl.

idioms.example: I’ve compromised enough in this negotiation. I’m ready to stand my ground.
idioms.origin: Alludes to one side in an armed conflict refusing to yield a position.

idioms.example: I’m happy to start the bidding. I’d like to go to Yellowstone for our vacation.
idioms.origin: Alludes to auctions and some card games, where the action is initiated when one party makes the first bid.

idioms.example: Nothing has been done on this project yet. We’re starting from scratch.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the line indicating the start of a race.

idioms.example: We need to stay the course regardless of the setbacks.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to horses having the stamina to remain on the course of a racetrack.

idioms.example: No, Andy hasn’t asked her to marry him yet, but stay tuned.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the phrase used in radio news broadcasting to encourage listeners to remain on the station for further developments.

idioms.example: Andy has been developing his patent application for months, but another company stole his thunder.
idioms.comment: Can imply that the idea is stolen.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the eighteenth-century invention of a mechanism for making the sound of thunder in a play, which the inventor claimed was stolen for use in another play.

idioms.example: If we’re not attentive, they could steal a march on us.
idioms.origin: Alludes to an army quietly marching to a new position of advantage on a battlefield.

idioms.example: We are losing too many sales. It’s time to stem the tide.
Andy needs to step up her game if she wants that promotion.
Andy really stepped up to the plate for us, so we need to show our appreciation.
idioms.origin: Alludes to baseball, where the batter steps up to home plate to  face the pitcher.

idioms.example: Andy is such a stick in the mud, not someone you want at a small dinner party.
I did well in the course but I didn’t quite stick the landing, so I just got an A-.
idioms.origin: Alludes to gymnastics and other aerial sports, where the phrase indicates performing a perfect landing.

idioms.example: They’ve tried hard to change his mind, but he’s sticking to his guns.
idioms.origin: Alludes to on a soldier remaining in place to fire a gun even when all appears to be lost.
Alludes to the sport of cricket, where a wicket that dries rapidly after rain is "sticky" and thus conducive to spinning the ball and making it harder to hit.

idioms.example: Andy is actually very disappointed, but she’s maintaining a stiff upper lip.
The troop is getting pretty complacent. I think we need to stir the pot.
I can handle this. Tuning skis is my stock in trade.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the goods kept in stock for carrying on a business or trade.
from being in the stocks?
Alludes to the historical hunting practice of tying a pigeon to stool to serve as a decoy for other pigeons.

idioms.example: I’ve gotten too many demerits. I need to stay on the straight and narrow for the rest of the term.
idioms.comment: Usually used with "stay on" or "stick to".
idioms.origin: Alludes to the Biblical phrase "strait is the gate, and narrow is the way, which leadeth unto life" (Matthew 7:14).

idioms.example: I know that we’re having a test on Tuesday. I got that straight from the horse’s mouth.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the practice of determining the age of a horse by looking in its mouth, or alludes to the notion that a racing tip came straight from one of the racehorses and hence must be reliable.

idioms.example: Andy has a strangle hold on first place in the tournament. The rest of us are playing for second best.
His opponents have created a straw man to attack because his real proposal is completely solid.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the use of straw figures as military training dummies.

idioms.example: We’re just sketching out a straw man here. Don’t take it too seriously.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the use of straw figures as military training dummies.

idioms.example: There’s a tremendous amount of useful information here. I think we’ve struck it rich.
idioms.comment: Can imply value that is not financial.

idioms.example: There’s a tremendous amount of useful information here. I think we’ve struck pay dirt.
idioms.comment: Can imply value that is not financial.
idioms.origin: Alludes to mining, where the phrase refers to discovering valuable ore in a claim.

idioms.keywords: strike while the iron is hot
idioms.example: We have waited a long time for this chance. We need to strike while the iron is hot.
idioms.origin: Alludes to blacksmithing, where iron can only be worked when it’s hot.

idioms.example: This is his standard stump speech. I’ve heard it too many times already.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the perhaps apocryphal story that early politicians stood on stumps to talk in village centers.

idioms.example: I think this office will suit me to a T.
This project is her swan song and she wants to do it right.
idioms.origin: Alludes to an ancient and unsubstantiated belief that swans sing a lovely song on dying.

idioms.example: Andy’s sweating bullets. She finds out today whether she passed the bar exam.
This place is a real sweat shop. They’re obsessive about work hours, lunches, and coffee breaks.
idioms.origin: Alludes to shops or factories in which employees work long hours at low wages under poor conditions.

idioms.example: They’ve been sweeping their problems under the rug for months, but the issues are getting too serious to hide any longer.
I’m getting better at using the new XXXX, but I haven’t quite found the sweet spot yet.
idioms.origin: Alludes to idea that there’s a spot on a tennis racquet, a golf club, a baseball bat, etc. that applies force most effectively.

idioms.example: Andy has several good job offers besides ours, so I think we need to sweeten the pot.
idioms.origin: Alludes to poker and other gambling games, where the phrase indicates adding money to the betting pool.

idioms.example: Andy is not taking any partial measures. He’s swinging for the fences.
idioms.origin: Alludes to baseball, where the phrase indicates a batter swinging for a home run.

idioms.paraphrase: a pair of people coordinating closely
idioms.example: Andy and I are working like a tag team to wear our boss down and get her agreement.
idioms.origin: Alludes to wrestling, where the phrase indicates a wrestler in the ring tagging another outside the ring to exchange places.

idioms.example: Andy and I are tag-teaming our boss to wear her down and get her agreement.
idioms.origin: Alludes to wrestling, where the phrase indicates a wrestler in the ring tagging another outside the ring to exchange places.

idioms.example: This is a case of the tail wagging the dog,  isn’t it? We’ve been responding to the demands of just one customer when we should be looking at our whole strategy.
Andy took her eye off the ball, so she didn’t do well on her exam.
idioms.origin: Alludes to baseball, tennis, or other sports where a player must hit a ball in motion.

idioms.keywords: take (one) (or (something)) with a grain of salt
idioms.example: Andy can be rather melodramatic. I always take his dramatics with a grain of salt.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the ancient discovery of an antidote for a poison where one of the antidote’s ingredients was a bit of salt.

idioms.example: Andy is way too cocky. Someone should take him down a peg.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice of raising and lowering a ship’s colors through the use of pegs, where lower colors signified less honor.

idioms.example: He thinks Andy really cares for him, but she’s taking him for a ride.
The coach is unhappy with Andy’s attitude, so she’s taking him to the woodshed.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the perhaps exaggerated story that children used to be taken to the woodshed for spanking or other corporal punishment.

idioms.example: She didn’t want to go to the movies, but her children took her by storm.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical military practice of sending a large formation of soldiers directly against a strong position.

idioms.example: That idea didn’t work very well. We need to take a different tack.
idioms.origin: Alludes to sailing, where a tack is when a boat sailing upwind turns its bow into and through the wind so that the direction from which the wind blows changes from one side of the boat to the other.

idioms.example: He couldn’t stand to face her, so he took a powder.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the speed and explosive nature of gunpowder.

idioms.example: I can’t make it this evening, so I’ll have to take a rain check.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice of giving patrons of an event that is canceled due to weather a credit (a "rain check") for a later event.

idioms.example: I wasn’t at all prepared for that meeting and I really took it on the chin.
idioms.origin: Alludes to boxing, where a strong blow to the opponent’s chin can be decisive.

idioms.example: After the students went behind her back, the professor was taking no prisoners.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the ancient military practice of slaughtering all the opposing forces rather than taking on the burden of managing prisoners.

idioms.example: This project was risky from the beginning and now it’s clearly taking on water.
idioms.origin: Alludes to what happens when a boat or ship begins to leak and starts to sink.

idioms.example: I told him it’s going to be just the two of us having a beer and he took the bait. He’ll be very surprised to see everyone there.
idioms.comment: Often implies that an enticement is disguised.
idioms.origin: Obviously alludes to fishing or hunting, where bait is used to entice a fish onto a hook or an animal into a trap.

idioms.example: Andy could see that the group wasn’t making any progress, so she took the bit in her teeth and got everyone back on track.
idioms.origin: Alludes to horseback riding, where a horse that gets the bit in its teeth, as opposed to behind them, no longer responds to commands through the reins.

idioms.example: Doesn’t that take the cake? The lowest ranked team won the tournament.
So far he’s been restrained in his counterarguments, but now he’s ready to take the gloves off.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to hockey, where players remove their gloves for a serious fight.

idioms.example: Andy isn’t really responsible for the problems, but she’s willing to take the heat for the whole group.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the use of fire as torture in Medieval Europe.

idioms.keywords: take the wind out of (one’s) sails
idioms.example: I hate to take the wind out of your sails, but there are no tickets left for the concert.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the technique in racing or naval warfare of positioning one sailing vessel to the windward of another so as to reduce the wind available to the leeward vessel for speed or maneuvering.

idioms.example: I was quite taken aback by her criticism.
idioms.origin: Alludes to sailing, where the phrase refers to the effect on a vessel of an unexpected contrary wind.

idioms.example: We’ve been working overtime for days now and we’re all tapped out. We can’t do any more.
Everything’s teed up. Just let us know when you’d like to start.
idioms.origin: Alludes to golf, where one places the ball on a tee to begin each hole.

idioms.example: You’re telegraphing your punches. They can always tell what you’re going to try next.
idioms.origin: Alludes to boxing, where the phrase indicates that a boxer is inadvertently revealing the direction that his or her punches are coming from.
nautical

idioms.example: I can tell you now that dog won’t hunt. The executives have already turned down similar proposals.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the use of dogs in hunting to locate prey.

idioms.example: OK, team, that’s a wrap. We’ve dealt with every outstanding item.
idioms.origin: film

idioms.example: Those two have been pals for years. They’re thick as thieves.

idioms.keywords: think outside (or out of) the box
idioms.example: None of the usual approaches have worked here. We need to start thinking outside the box.
The student council doesn’t believe his account, so they’re giving Andy the third degree in there.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the highest rank in freemasonry, termed the "third degree, achieved by passing an intense interrogation.

idioms.comment: Typically used in politics
idioms.origin: Alludes to the middle rail of an electric railway, which is electrified and dangerous, if not fatal, to touch.

idioms.example: We shouldn’t let him drive. He’s three sheets to the wind.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the loss of control of a sailing vessels when any of its sheets is loose or "in the wind".

idioms.example: You’ve had your three strikes with her, pal. I don’t think she wants to go out with you.
idioms.origin: Alludes to baseball, where a batter who gets three strikes is out.

idioms.example: With those 4 kids, their house is always a 3-ring circus.
Andy’s gone through the looking glass with these conspiracy theories.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the Lewis Carroll book "Through the Looking Glass, in which the character of Alice climbs through a mirror and enters a world where everything is reversed.

idioms.example: With handling his father’s death on top of the crisis at this job, Andy’s been through the wringer lately.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to the wringer on a vintage washing machine that was used to squeeze the water out of wet clothes.

idioms.keywords: throw (one’s) hat in (or into) the ring
idioms.example: Andy doesn’t really want to be president, but we convinced him to throw his hat in the ring.
idioms.origin: Alludes to boxing, where historically one issued a challenge by throwing a hat into the ring.

idioms.example: The teacher sure threw us a curve ball today. I thought this was supposed to be an easy test.
idioms.origin: Alludes to baseball, where a curve ball is one of the trickier pitches to hit.

idioms.example: These reporters are supposed to be tough, but they’re just throwing the mayor softballs.
idioms.origin: Alludes to slow-pitch softball, where a pitched ball is relatively easy to hit.

idioms.example: The senator would not take responsibility for the smear campaign, so he threw his most junior aide under the bus instead.

idioms.keywords: throw (oneself) on the mercy of the court
idioms.example: Andy can’t deny his mistake, so all he can do is throw himself on the mercy of the court.
I’ve tried and failed several times to get this project approved, so I’m throwing in my hand.
idioms.origin: Alludes to to poker, where the phrase refers to folding or resigning from the current hand.

idioms.example: I’ve tried and failed several times to get this project approved, so I’m throwing in the towel.
idioms.origin: Alludes to boxing, where a boxer’s manager can concede defeat by throwing a towel into the ring.

idioms.example: He’s had his chances to go straight but he’s always failed, and now the judge is throwing the book at him.
idioms.origin: Alludes to charging someone in court with every applicable legal offense and applying maximum punishment.

idioms.example: Having those two work together on a project is a ticking time bomb.

idioms.origin: Probably alludes to ships historically riding the tide when entering or leaving port.

idioms.example: He really tied one on after Andy broke up with him.
Andy’s a well-organized manager and she runs a tight ship.
idioms.origin: Alludes to a well-maintained sailing vessel, where sheets and stays are all kept taut.

idioms.example: Andy tends to see problems where none exist. She’s always tilting at windmills.
idioms.comment: Can imply that the target is also insurmountable.
idioms.origin: Alludes to Miguel Cervantes’ novel "The Ingenious Gentleman Don Quixote of La Mancha, in which the protagonist attacks windmills that he believes to be giants.

idioms.example: If you’re hoping to change her mind, be subtle about it. Don’t tip your hand right away.
idioms.origin: Alludes to card games, where it’s a disadvantage to allow one’s opponents to see one’s hand of cards.

idioms.example: They’re working to beat the band. I can’t believe how much progress they’ve made.
idioms.origin: Alludes to making enough noise to drown out a loud band.
sword fighting

idioms.example: What a tone deaf remark that was. He offended everyone in the room with that one.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the inability to distinguish musical tones.

idioms.keywords: too many balls in the air
idioms.example: With 3 kids, a job, and a sick husband, Andy just has too many balls in the air.
idioms.origin: Alludes to juggling, where the object is keep multiple balls or other objects in the air.

idioms.keywords: too many irons in the fire
idioms.example: I can’t take on another project. I’ve got too many irons in the fire already.
idioms.origin: Alludes to blacksmithing, where an overly busy blacksmith might have too many pieces of iron heating up in the fire at once.

idioms.example: They’ve been avoiding this conflict for too long, so now they’re going at it tooth and nail.
idioms.origin: Alludes to biting and scratching in an all-out fight.

idioms.example: The top brass liked our idea after all, so now we have to get to work.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the British military, where senior officers historically wore brass or gold insignia.

idioms.example: Andy is a top hand. It would be great to have her on our project.
idioms.origin: Alludes to ranching in the American west, where the phrase historically indicated a very capable cowboy.

idioms.example: Andy’s very detail oriented, so make sure you touch all the bases with your proposal.
idioms.origin: Alludes to baseball, where a baserunner must touch every base that he or she passes.

idioms.example: We weren’t at all sure she would pass her tests. It was definitely touch and go for a while.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the risk posed when two vessels make contact but avoid serious collision.

idioms.example: Please touch base with me before you leave for the weekend.
idioms.origin: Alludes to baseball, where after a fly ball is caught a baserunner must touch base before running.

idioms.example: Andy has a very good track record in solving this exact type of problem.
We’re just treading water here, waiting on management to commit the resources we need.
idioms.origin: Alludes to swimming, where the phrase indicates maintaining one’s position in deep water with circular hand motions.

idioms.example: I sent up a trial balloon with this concept and I didn’t detect much enthusiasm.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the practice of launching balloons, usually with instruments attached, to determine weather conditions.

idioms.example: This is a tried-and-true technique. I’ve never known it to fail.
Andy was getting too careless on his own. We had to clip his wings.
idioms.origin: Alludes to clipping a bird’s wings to prevent it from flying.

idioms.example: I thought Andy was on our side, but we’re seeing his true colors now.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the historical practice of warships or pirate ships flying a false flag to misidentify themselves and then hoisting their true flag once the deception has been effective.

idioms.example: The teacher always turns a blind eye to Andy’s misbehavior.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the action of the British Admiral Nelson in the Battle of the Nile, where he intentionally ignored a signal to withdraw by placing his telescope to his blind eye.

idioms.example: I generally turn into a pumpkin after 9pm.
idioms.origin: Alludes to one version of the fairy tale "Cinderella, where the heroine must leave the ball and return to her hovel by midnight or her magic carriage will turn back into a pumpkin.

idioms.example: He’s insulted me too often. I can no longer turn the other cheek.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the Biblical story (Luke 6:29) in which Jesus urges his followers to love their enemies and, when struck on one cheek, turn the other and allow it to be struck.

idioms.example: Andy’s so-called friends left her twisting in the wind when it was time to take responsibility.
idioms.comment: Implies abandonment by supposed allies.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the corpse of a hanged person left dangling and twisting in the open air as a warning to others.

idioms.example: I put in my two cents worth, but no one wanted my advice.
idioms.origin: Alludes to a similar British phrase of unclear origin that uses "twopence" or "tuppence" instead of "two cents".

idioms.example: Andy likes to take new employees under her wing and help them get adjusted.
idioms.origin: Alludes to a chicken or other fowl keeping her chicks under her wing for protection.

idioms.example: They’ve just shortened our deadline! Now we’re really under the gun.
Andy really likes to get under the hood. You can expect her to check every detail.
idioms.origin: Alludes to repairing automobiles, where the phrase indicates to work on the basic mechanisms and parts of the engine.

idioms.example: Andy often operates under the radar until she’s sure of her results.
idioms.origin: Alludes to flying a spy or war plane so low that it cannot be detected by radar.

idioms.example: They’ve been paying their workers in cash and under the table.
idioms.comment: Can imply illegality as well as secrecy.
idioms.origin: Alludes to money being passed secretively and out of sight, as in a bribe.
Obviously alludes to the fact that a completely drunk person is likely to end up on the floor.
Possibly alludes to the perceived influence of weather on one’s health.
By extension, alludes to the phrase being used to signify that someone is sick.

idioms.example: You can argue until the cows come home, but you won’t change her mind.
idioms.origin: Probably alludes to bringing the milk cows in late in the afternoon in preparation for milking them the following morning.

idioms.example: The government’s involvement in this case certainly ups the ante.
idioms.origin: Alludes to gambling games, where the ante is the amount one must pay up front to play the game.

idioms.example: I’m definitely not up to scratch today after being sick all week.
idioms.origin: Alludes to boxing, where historically a boxer indicated readiness by stepping up to a line scratched in the dirt.

idioms.example: I’m definitely not up to snuff today after being sick all week.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the effect of snuff in making someone more alert and awake.

idioms.example: I had no idea that Andy’s friends were so upper crust.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the preferred crust of a pie or load of bread.

idioms.example: I don’t want to upset the applecart, but you’re missing some important information.

idioms.paraphrase: the people who are usually involved
idioms.example: I thought there might be some new faces at lunch, but it was just the usual suspects.
idioms.origin: Of unknown origin, but famously used in the final scenes of the 1942 film Casablanca.

idioms.example: Why do I feel like I’ve been voted off the island? Did I offend someone?
idioms.origin: Alludes to the reality television show Survivor that was set in an isolated location, often an island, and in which individuals are eliminated from the competition by being voted out by other competitors.

idioms.keywords: waiting for the other shoe to drop
idioms.example: So far it seems like all good news, but we keep waiting for the other shoe to drop.
idioms.comment: Implies that good news has already been received.
idioms.origin: Alludes to waiting for one’s neighbor in the apartment above to remove and drop their second shoe after the first has been removed and dropped on the floor.

idioms.example: Andy’s been waiting in the wings for too long and she’s getting impatient.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the offstage area of a theater (the "wings") where actors wait until their presence is required onstage.

idioms.paraphrase: rouse a powerful force from inactivity
idioms.example: Please don’t make Andy angry. You’d be waking a sleeping giant.
idioms.origin: Possibly alludes to the fairy tale "Jack and the Beanstalk, in which Jack disturbs a giant whom he must then escape.

idioms.example: Getting that low grade was a real wake-up call for me.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the service commonly available in hotels of calling a room at a requested time to wake up the guests.

idioms.example: What a walk in the park that test was!
Andy’s being made to walk the plank even though the failure wasn’t her fault.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the perhaps apocryphal tradition that pirates disposed of captives or offenders by tying their hands and forcing them to walk off a plank into the ocean.

idioms.example: She’s been very touchy lately and I’ve been walking on eggshells around her.
The board feels so betrayed that they want the director’s head on a platter.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the Biblical story (Mark 6:21-28 and Matthew 15:6-11) in which Salome requests as a reward the head of John the Baptist on a platter.

idioms.example: The company has accumulated quite a war chest in anticipation of a huge engineering effort.
idioms.comment: Usually implies financial resources.

idioms.example: I’ve washed my hands of that project. I want nothing more to do with it.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the Biblical account (Matthew 27:24) of Pontius Pilate absolving himself of responsibility for the crucifixion of Jesus by washing his hands.

idioms.paraphrase: we’ve entered a very different environment
idioms.example: People react very differently here. We’re sure not in Kansas anymore.
idioms.origin: Alludes to the Frank Baum novel The Wonderful Wizard of Oz (and its well-known film adaptation The Wizard of Oz), in which the heroine Dorothy, on arriving in the magical land of Oz, says to her dog Toto, "we’re not in Kansas anymore".

idioms.example: I think I’m the weak link in this group. You all have more experience than I do.
idioms.origin: Obviously alludes to the fact that one weak link in a chain can lead to its failure under stress.

idioms.example: I’m not sure who wears the pants in their relationship.

idioms.origin: nautical

idioms.example: Andy, would you like to weigh in on this discussion?
idioms.origin: boxing, racing

idioms.example: He’s a bit wet behind the ears, but I’m hopeful he’ll learn quickly.
I hate to be a wet blanket, but we’ve got to get home.

idioms.paraphrase: there’s something wrong in this situation

idioms.example: The project went really well for several months, but now the wheels are coming off.

idioms.comment: Usually used facetiously.

idioms.example: I’m not at all sure why we’re doing things this way, but when in Rome.
idioms.comment: Understood to be followed by: "do as the Romans do"

idioms.paraphrase: when the crisis is at hand
idioms.example: You can always count on Andy when the chips are down.
idioms.origin: poker

idioms.example: Andy’s absolutely dependable when the chips are down.
idioms.origin: Gambling

idioms.example: Even though we’re all at fault, the boss has found his whipping boy.
idioms.comment: Often implies punishing a blameless individual.
idioms.origin: a stand-in for the prince, who couldn’t be whipped

idioms.example: Andy looks unconcerned about her tests, but I think she’s whistling past the graveyard.

idioms.origin: revered white elephant, allegedly given as gifts by kings of Siam to ruin the recipient

idioms.example: Practically everyone in Marketing is here at the conference,so who’s minding the store?
Andy fell for their story whole hog.
They sold us the house and everything in it — the whole kit and caboodle.
That’s the whole nine yards. We have no more resources to draw on.
idioms.origin: WWI ammo belts for S. Pacific fighter planes were 9 yds long.  Firing everything was giving it the whole 9 yds.

idioms.example: There were no other parts or pieces in the package. This is the whole shooting match.
You can always tell whose ox is gored. It’s the people who complain the loudest.
Andy’s the wild card here. No one knows what her capabilities are.
idioms.origin: poker

idioms.example: The fifth grade has a substitute teacher and it’s the wild west in there today.

idioms.origin: will he or won’t (nil) he?

idioms.example: She’s not well prepared. She’s going out there on a wing and a prayer.
I was completely unprepared, so I just winged it in front of the whole class.
idioms.origin: theater—getting coached from the wings
horse racing

idioms.example: They’re both vying for the job, but I think Andy holds the winning hand.
idioms.origin: gambling/cards

idioms.paraphrase: a search for someone to blame
idioms.example: Nothing really happened at the party, but the parents seem to be on a witch hunt anyway.
idioms.comment: Often implies that the grounds for blame are flimsy.
idioms.origin: Salem witch trials

idioms.example: Andy graduated from law school with flying colors.
idioms.origin: naval?

idioms.example: Andy was really angry and he came at them with guns blazing.
idioms.origin: cowboys

idioms.example: I knew I needed to placate her, so I went into her office with hat in hand.
There’s no backup plan if we fail. We’re proceeding without a net.
idioms.origin: circuses

idioms.example: Andy aced every test without breaking a sweat.

idioms.paraphrase: (one) feels immensely successful and able to accomplish anything desired

idioms.example: Andy has proved he’s worth his salt.
They say she’s from the wrong side of the tracks, but no one really knows her background.
idioms.comment: Can imply a shady background.

idioms.example: The new hires are a bunch of young Turks who expect to change the way we do things.
idioms.origin: Turkish history

idioms.example: I got good results with the latest version, but your mileage may vary.
idioms.origin: Disclaimers in auto ads

idioms.example: Come on, your nose is growing with every word out of your mouth. It’s time to tell us the truth.
idioms.origin: Pinocchio
